Rosaura believes that working with Manuela Ramos is a great support for all women who want to start their own business and obtain capital to continue growing and to give a better future to their loved ones.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Rosaura pertenece al Banco Comunal Ricardo Palma, ubicado en el Jr. Elmer Faucett 839, del Distrito D. Calleria del Departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 59 años es madre D. 6 hijos, su esposo es jubilado, pero el ingreso que tiene no le alcanza para su economía diaria, es así que Rosaura con el primer préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidió invertirlo en el negocio D. venta D. mercadería. En la actualidad continua con su negocio D. mercadería, se levanta muy temprano para realizar las labores domesticas, y en las tardes sale a comprar la mercadería que llevara para venderla en los diferentes caseríos D. nuestra ciudad. Con este préstamo recibido D. S/. 1,000, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará mercaderías como polos, vestidos, faldas, camisas, pantalones, etc, para damas, caballeros y niños. Rosaura trabajar con Manuela Ramos es un apoyo para todas las mujeres que quieren emprender un negocio y tener capital para seguir creciendo y poder dar un futuro mejor a sus seres mas queridos.

loans.use: Purchase of additional clothing/merchandise to sell

loans.name: Tania

texts.es:
Tania belongs to the communal bank Ricardo Palma, located at Jr. Las Gaviotas Mz 44 Lt. 6, in the Yarina Cocha District in the region of Ucayali. She is 30 years old and is a mother of 3 children. Her husband works at a company. With her first loan of 300 Peruvian Nuevos Soles from the Manuela Ramos organization she decided to invest in a retail business.

Currently she sells phone cards. In the mornings she takes care of her children and works selling her cards and in the evenings she studys.

With this loan of 1,300 Nuevos Soles, which will be repaid in 5 months, she will buy cards for prepaid cell phones using Movistar for long distance and local calls.

Tania is a very selfless mother that studies in order to be able to offer better opportunities to her children. With the loans she has received, she can contribute to the household earnings and feel more independent.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Tania pertenece al Banco Comunal Ricardo Palma, ubicado en el Jr. Las Gaviotas Mz 44 Lt. 6, del Distrito de Yarina Cocha del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 30 años es madre de 3 hijos, su esposo trabaja en una compañía. Tania con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidió invertir en la venta de mercadería.

En la actualidad se dedica a la venta de tarjetas telefónicas, en las mañanas se ocupa de sus hijos y se dirige a vender sus tarjetas, y por las noches estudia.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,300, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará tarjetas para celulares claro, movistar, para larga distancia, local.

Tania es una madre muy abnegada estudia para poder brindarles mejores oportunidades a sus hijos con los prestamos recibidos, puede contribuir a la economía de su hogar y sentirme mas independiente.

loans.use: Buying phone cards for celular phone in order to sell

loans.name: Emilda

texts.es:
Emilda belongs to the communal bank Santa Rosa de Lima, located in the neighborhood of San Juan Bautista Mz. b Lt. 14, in the Callería District in the region of Ucayali. She is 58 years old and is a mother of 9 children. Her husband works in a boat providing transportation services. With her first loan of 300 Peruvian Nuevos Soles from the Manuela Ramos organization she decided to invest in a small grocery store.

Currently she is continuing to work in her grocery store with the help of her children, whom share the household work in order to be able help their mother.

With this loan of 3,000 Nuevos Soles, which will be paid in 4 months, she will buy 1 bag of rice, 1 bag of sugar, 1 case of milk, 1 case of oil, 2 packages of noodles, 1 bag of detergents, 2 cases of canned foods, toothpaste, shampoo, bleach, etc.

Emilda is very satisfied with all that she is achieving with her business. Her children are in good health and her husband supports her and this fills her with much joy.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Emilda pertenece al Banco Comunal Santa Rosa de Lima, ubicado en el Asentamiento. Humano. San Juan Bautista Mz. A Lt. 14, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 58 años es madre de 9 hijos, su esposo es motorista. Emilda con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidió invertirlo en una pequeña bodega.

En la actualidad continua con su bodega que atiende con la ayuda de sus hijos y se reparten las tareas domesticas para poder así ayudar a su mamá.

Con este préstamo de S/. 3,000, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará 1 saco de arroz, 1 saco de azúcar, 1 caja de leche, 1 caja de aceite, 2 paquetes de fideos, 1 bolsa de detergentes, 2 cajas de conservas, pasta dental, champú, lejía, etc.

Emilda esta muy contenta por todo lo que esta logrando con su negocio sus hijos se encuentran bien de salud su esposo la apoya y todo eso la llena de mucha alegría.

loans.use: Buying merchandise for her grocery store

loans.name: Dorti

texts.es:
Dorti belongs to the communal bank Santa Rosa de Lima, located in the neighborhood of San Juan Bautista Mz. b Lt. 28, in the Callería District in the region of Ucayali. She is 36 years old and is a mother of 3 children. Her husband works operating their small boat. With her first loan of 300 Peruvian Nuevos Soles from the Manuela Ramos organization she decided to invest in a boat to use to provide transporation service.

Currently, she has finished paying for her boat in which, together with her husband, they work providing transportation services to different neighborhoods in the city.

With this loan of 1,000 Nuevos Soles, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy fuel, oil and spare parts for her boat.

Dorti feels more independent and fulfilled with the support that the Manuela Ramos organization offers with its loans.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Dorti pertenece al Banco Comunal Santa Rosa de Lima, ubicado en el Asentamiento. Humano. San Juan Bautista Mz. b Lt. 28, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 36 años es madre de 3 hijos, su esposo es motorista. Dorti con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidió invertirlo en un bote para servicio colectivo.

En la actualidad termino de pagar su bote que junto a su esposo trabajan haciendo colectivo a los diferentes caseríos de nuestra ciudad.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará petróleo, aceite y repuestos para su bote.

Dorti se siente mas independiente y realizada por el apoyo que le brinda Manuela Ramos con sus préstamos.

loans.use: Buying fuel, oil and spare parts for her boat

loans.name: Loida

texts.es:
Loida belongs to the communal bank Vecinas Unidas (United Neighbors), located at Psj Biedma 168, in the Callería District in the region of Ucayali. She is 53 years old and is a mother of 4 children. Her husband is a retired professor. With her first loan of 300 Peruvian Nuevos Soles from the Manuela Ramos organization she decided to invest in a business making and selling wantanes (Chinese-style wontons) and corbatitas (bow-tie pasta).

She wakes up at 7AM. in order to prepare breakfast for her children and husband and then works preparing her wontons that she later sells at the market, with the help of her children, until 6PM.

With this loan of 1,800 Nuevos Soles, which will be repaid in 5 months, she will buy 1 bag of flour, 1 kilo of chuño (dehydrated potatoes), 1 package of oil, 1 machine for sealing bags, and polyethylene bags.

Loida is very happy, since she is little by little getting ahead with her family with her effort and work, together with the support of her children whom are her reason for being. She is very grateful for the support that the Manuela Ramos organization has given to her.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Loida pertenece al Banco Comunal Vecinas Unidas, ubicado en el Psj Biedma 168, del Distrito D. Calleria del Departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 53 años y es madre D. 4 hijos, su esposo es profesor jubilado. Loida con el primer préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidió invertirlo en un negocio D. preparación y venta D. wantanes y corbatitas.

En la actualidad ella cuenta con un negocio D. preparación y venta D. wantanes, se levanta a las 7 am para preparar el desayuno D. sus hijos y D. su esposo, luego se dedica a la preparación D. sus wantanes, con la ayuda D. sus hijos D. allí los venD. en el mercado hasta las 6 pm.

Con este préstamo D. S/. 1,800, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, compro: 1 saco D. harina, 1 kg D. chuño, 1 paquete D. aceite, 1 selladora, bolsas D. polietileno.

Loida esta muy feliz, ya que ella misma paso a paso esta sacando adelante a su familia con su esfuerzo y trabajo junto con el apoyo D. sus hijos que son su razón D. ser, ella esta muy agradecida con el apoyo que le da Manuela Ramos para su negocio

loans.use: Buying raw materials to use in her baked goods

loans.name: Laura Senita

texts.es:
Laura belongs to the communal bank Vecinas Unidas (United Neighbors), located at Jr. Ucayali No. 875, in the Callería District in the region of Ucayali. She is 43 years old and is the mother of 3 young children. Her husband is a professor. With her first loan of 300 Peruvian Soles from the Manuela Ramos organization she decided to invest in selling beauty products.

Currently she has a business selling beauty products and making little towels. She wakes up at 7AM. in order to prepare breakfast for her children and husband and works selling her beauty products and making the towels until 8PM.

With this loan of 1,000 Peruvian Soles, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will by 10 meters of cloth of different colors, silk lace, ribbons, threads, creams, perfumes, talc, cologne, deodorants, etc.

Laura is very happy, her business grows every day and now she can buy many things that she has so wanted. Her family is happy for her and very grateful to the Manuela Ramos organization for the support of her business.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Laura pertenece al Banco Comunal Vecinas Unidas, ubicado en el Jr Ucayali No 875, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 43 años y es madre de 3 hijos menores de edad, su esposo es profesor. Laura con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decidió invertirlo en la venta de productos de belleza. En la actualidad ella cuenta con un negocio de venta de productos de bellaza y de confección de toallitas, se levanta a las 7.00 a.m. Para preparar el desayuno de sus hijos, y de su esposo y de se dedica a la venta de sus productos de belleza y a la confección de sus toallitas hasta las 8 pm. Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000, el cual Será pagado en 4 meses, comprará 10 metros de tela de colores, blondas, cintas, hilos, cremas, perfumes, talcos, colonias, desodorantes, etc. Laura esta muy alegre, su negocio crece cada día, ahora puede comprarse muchas cosas que tanto quería, su familia esta feliz por ella, y esta muy agradecida a Manuela Ramos por el apoyo dado para su negocio.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Maria Angela

texts.es:
María Angela belongs to the communal bank Santa Rosa de Lima, located in the neighborhood of San Juan Bautista Mz. D Lt. 4, in Callería District in the region of Ucayali. She is 43 years old and has 4 children and her husband is a driver. With the first loan of 300 Peruvian Soles that María received from the Manuela Ramos organization she decided to invest in an auto rickshaw.

Currently she rents out her auto rickshaw in order to earn more income for her family and to be able to educate her children.

With this loan of 1,500 Peruvian Soles, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will invest in maintenance for her rickshaw and buying spare parts.

María is very happy and is thinking about buying another rickshaw with the support that the Manuel Ramos organization provides to her through the loans.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maria Angela pertenece al Banco Comunal Santa Rosa de Lima, ubicado en el Asentamiento. Humano. San Juan Bautista Mz. D Lt. 4, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 43 años es madre de 4 hijos, su esposo es chofer. María con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidió invertirlo en un motocarro. En la actualidad alquila su motocarro para que genere mas ingresos a su familia y poder hace educar sus hijos. Con este préstamo de S/. 1,500, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, lo invertirá con en el mantenimiento de su motocarro y en comprar algunas piezas. Maria esta muy contenta y esta pensando comprar otro motocarro con el apoyo que le brinda Manuela Ramos en los préstamos.

loans.use: For maintenance of her auto rickshaw

loans.name: Luz

texts.es:
Luz is a member of the Vecinas Unidas (United Neighbors) Community Bank, which is located at No. 1299 Bellavista Avenue in the Calleria district, in the state of Ucayali. She is 50 years old and has two grown children. Her husband is a secretary. Luz invested her first loan of 300 soles from Manuela Ramos in a dress making and shoe sales business.

Luz now owns her business making clothes, selling shoes and making hand towels. She gets up at 7:00 in the morning to make breakfast for her children and husband. After that she turns to making clothes and towels and selling shoes until 7:00 in the evening.

With this loan of 1,000 soles (apprximately $375), which will be paid back in four months, Luz will purchase shoes, different colored fabrics, silk lace, ribbons, thread, shoe polish, perfume, talc, cologne, and deodorizer, etc.

Luz is very happy that her business is growing every day. Now she can buy many things that she has really wanted. Her family are happy for her and she is very thankful to Manuela Ramos for the support it has provided to her business.

Translated by Todd Anderson, Kiva volunteer

La señora Luz pertenece al Banco Comunal Vecinas Unidas, ubicado en la Av. Bellavista No 1299, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 50 años y es madre de 2 hijos mayores de edad, su esposo es secretario. Luz con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decidió invertirlo en un negocio de confección y venta de zapatos.

En la actualidad ella cuenta con un negocio de confección ,venta de zapatos y confección de toallitas, se levanta a las 7.00 a.m. Para preparar el desayuno de sus hijos, y de su esposo y de se dedica a la confección y venta de sus toallitas y de sus zapatos, hasta las 7 pm.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000, el cual Será pagado en 4 meses, comprará zapatos, telas de diferentes colores, blondas, cintas, hilos, cremas, perfumes, talcos, colonias, desodorantes, etc.

Luz esta muy alegre, su negocio crece cada día, ahora puede comprarse muchas cosas que tanto quería, su familia esta feliz por ella, y esta muy agradecida a Manuela Ramos por el apoyo dado para su negocio.

loans.use: Purchase of additional merchandise for sale

loans.name: Violeta

texts.es:
Violeta belongs to "Banco Comunal Vecinas Unidas", located in "`Jr Agustín Cauper 167, del Distrito D. Calleria del Departamento D. Ucayali". She is 48 years old and mother of 6 children. However, her income is not enough to support her family. WIth the first loan she received, she invested on some clothes for her store.

She currently owns a store which has clothes for men, women and children. She wakes up every morning at 7am in order to prepare breakfast for her kids. She then heads to her store in which she works until 9pm.

With this loan of S/. 1,000, which will be paid back in 4 months, she will buy more clothes, fabrics of diverse colors and forms, needles, threads, etc.

Violeta is very happy, her business is improving every day. She still remembers when she began and is happy to be able to support her family. She has become a hard-working woman and is very happy for the support she has received.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Peterson, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Violeta pertenece al Banco Comunal Vecinas Unidas, ubicado en el Jr Agustín Cauper 167, del Distrito D. Calleria del Departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 48 años y es madre D. 6 hijos, pero los ingresos económicos que tiene no le alcanzan para mantener los gastos familiares, Violeta con el primer préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidió invertirlo en el negocio D. confecciones D. ropas. En la actualidad ella cuenta con un negocio D. bazar y confecciones D. ropas para damas, caballeros y niños, se levanta a las7am para preparar el desayuno D. sus hijos y D. allí se dedica a la atención D. su bazar y confección D. sus prendas hasta las 9 pm. Con este préstamo D. S/. 1,000, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará pasamanería, telas D. diversas formas y colores, blondas, hilos, etc. Violeta esta muy feliz y contenta, su negocio esta mejorando cada día y no olvida que cuando empezó todo era distinto ahora ella pueD. sacar adelante a su familia valiéndose por si misma, se ha convertido en una mujer luchadora, ella esta muy agradecida con el apoyo que le da Manuela Ramos para su negocio.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise for her store

loans.name: Sofia

texts.es:
Sofia is a member of the Vecinas Unidas (United Neighbors) Community Bank, which is located at No. 480 Eduardo del Aguila Jr in the Calleria district, in the state of Ucayali. She is 48 years old and has five children. Her husband is a civil servant. Sofia invested her first loan of 300 soles from Manuela Ramos in a business selling snacks.

Sofia now owns her food and refreshments business. She gets up at 6:00 in the morning to make breakfast for her children and husband. After that she sells snacks near a school entrance until 1:00 in the afternoon.

With this loan of 1,000 soles (approximately $375), which will be paid back in four months, Sofia will purchase a sack of sugar, a sack of rice, oil, fried plantain chips, and five boxes of soft drinks.

Sofia is very proud of herself: her business is growing every day thanks to her determination to get ahead and support her children’s studies. Her children are her reason for being and for pressing forward. Sofia is also very thankful to Manuela Ramos for the support it has provided to her business.

Translated by Todd Anderson, Kiva volunteer

La señora Sofía pertenece al Banco Comunal Vecinas Unidas, ubicado en el Jr Morona 144, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 48 años y es madre de 5 hijos, su esposo es empleado publico. Sofía con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidió invertirlo en un negocio de venta de refrigerios.

En la actualidad ella cuenta con un negocio de venta de comida y de refrigerios, se levanta a las 6 am para preparar el desayuno de sus hijos y de su esposo, después se dedica a la venta de sus comidas y refrigerios en la puerta de un colegio hasta la 1 pm.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará 1 saco de azúcar, 1 saco de arroz, aceite, chifles, 5 cajas de gaseosa. etc.

Sofía esta muy orgullosa de si misma, su negocio esta creciendo cada día debido al empeño que ella le pone para salir adelante y así poder apoyar en los estudios a sus hijos pues son su razón de ser y de seguir adelante, ella esta muy agradecida con el apoyo que le da Manuela Ramos para su negocio.

loans.use: Purchase of additional supplies for preparing food for sale

loans.name: Nelly

texts.es:
Nelly is a member of the Vecinas Unidas (United Neighbors) Community Bank, which is located at No. 480 Eduardo del Aguila Jr in the Calleria district, in the state of Ucayali. She is 36 years old and has two young children. Nelly invested her first loan of 300 soles from Manuela Ramos in the purchase of a three-wheeled motor cart, which she now owns.

Nelly gets up at 7:00 in the morning to make breakfast for her children. She then loans her motor cart to a chauffer who drives it.

With this loan of 1,200 soles (approximately $450), which will be paid back in four months, Nelly will make her first installment payment toward purchase of another motor cart.

Nelly is very satisfied that her business continues to grow each day. Now she is able to buy lots of things she always wanted and her family is happy for her. She also is very thankful to Manuela Ramos for the support it has provided to her business.

Translated by Todd Anderson, Kiva volunteer

La señora Nelly pertenece al Banco Comunal Vecinas Unidas, ubicado en el Jr Eduardo del águila No 480, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 36 años y es madre de 2 hijos menores de edad. Nelly con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decidió invertirlo en la compra de un motocarro.

En la actualidad ella cuenta con un motocarro, se levanta a las 7.00 a.m. Para preparar el desayuno de sus hijos, y de allí entrega su motocarro a su chofer para que lo maneje.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,200, el cual Será pagado en 4 meses, lo invertirá en el pago de la cuota inicial para la adquisición de otro motocarro.

Nelly esta muy contenta, su negocio crece cada día, ahora puede comprarse muchas cosas que tanto quería, su familia esta feliz por ella, y esta muy agradecida a Manuela Ramos por el apoyo dado para su negocio.

loans.use: First payment for new motor cart

loans.name: Fatima's Group

texts.es:
Fatima and Carmen belong to the communal bank called 'Torcaza'. Fatima has been a member for 1 year and Carmen for about 8 months.

Fatima is 28 years old and single. Fatima goes to the different fairs in the region where she purchases cereals, cheeses, and small animals which she then sells at the local supermarket called Nery Garcia. Also, Fatima has been selling clothes in the supermarket called Las Americas for the past month.

Carmen is a 30 year-old single mother. She has one daughter. Carmen owns a pharmacy located in the central square in the city of Ayacucho. She has been doing this for the past 7 months.

Fatima and Carmen need a loan of about $150 usd each. This money will be used to purchase clothes such as pants, shirts, intimate apparel, beauty products and medicine.

Fatima and Carmen wish to one day own a huge super-store, to help their sisters and to fully stock the pharmacy.

Translated from Spanish by Carolina Zelaya-Kronlund, Kiva Volunteer.

Fátima y Carmen pertenecen al Banco Comunal Torcaza hace 1 año y 8 meses respectivamente.

Fátima es soltera y tiene 28 años, Fátima viaja a las diferentes ferias de la región donde compra cereales, quesos y animales menores, que vende en el mercado Nery García. Además Fátima vende ropa en el mercado Las Américas, actividad que esta realizando hace 1 mes.

Mientras que Carmen es madre soltera, tiene 30 años y 1 hija, Carmen tiene una farmacia ubicada en una calle céntrica de la ciudad de Ayacucho, actividad que realiza hace 7 meses.

Fátima y Carmen necesitan préstamos de 400 soles cada una, dinero que será invertido en la compra de pantalones, polos, medias, productos de tocador y medicinas.

Los sueños de Fátima y Carmen son tener una tienda grande, ayudar a sus hermanas e implementar más su farmacia.

loans.use: Fatima and Carmen need a loan of about $150 usd each to purchase clothes such as pants, shirts, intimate apparel, beauty products and medicine.

loans.name: Taga A Centre - Group 1

texts.en:
For these 6 women of Taga A on the island of Savaii, these are their first loans from SPBD. They all undertook 4 weeks of training on managing a business, maintained a savings account, and then passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

Elise T. (32, married, 1 child), Loluama F. (22, married, no children), Sina A. (58, married, 7 children) and Lagomau N. (34, married, 5 children) all sell taro, yams, and bananas--staples of the Samoan diet--at the market. With their loans, they wish to purchase a weed killer, knives, shovels, seeds, an axe, and other equipment for farming.

Olepa V. (25, married, 3 children) is also in the farming business, but she has a different product line than the other women. She sells tomatoes, cucumbers, cabbages, sugar cane, and tauaga (used to squeeze coconuts for the juice). With her loan, she will purchase onions, sugar, carrots, potatoes, salt, and noodles.

Sina L. (33, married, 3 children) is requesting a loan in order to help her husband, a taxi driver for over 5 years, maintain his taxi. She is requesting money to purchase 4 tires and taxi parts.

loans.use: Purchase various farming tools for plantation farming

loans.name: Jheny Marisol

texts.es:
Jheny has belonged to the Community Bank 2000 for two years. Jheny is a single mother, 36 years old and has two children. Jheny sells consumer products and works for a distribution company. She sells in the city of Ayuchucho, Huanta, and plans to create a computer game room for children. Jheny needs a loan of 2000 soles to invest in the purchase of a washing machine for her house and a computer game. The dreams of Jheny are that her children will become professionals and build the second floor of her house.

Translated from Spanish by Helen C.Smith, Kiva Volunteer.

Jheny pertenece al Banco Comunal Dos Mil hace 2 años.

Jheny es madre soltera, tiene 36 años y 2 hijos, Jheny es agente vendedora de productos de consumo, trabaja para una empresa distribuidora. Sus ventas lo realiza en la ciudad de Ayacucho y Huanta. Jheny tiene proyectado implementar un salón de juegos electrónicos para niños.

Jheny necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de una lavadora para su casa y un juego electrónico.

Los sueños de Jheny son que sus hijos sean profesionales y construir la segunda planta de su casa.

loans.use: Jheny needs a loan of 2000 soles to buy a washing machine for her home and a computer game.

loans.name: Bolivia Group

texts.es:
Weaving alpaca sweaters and sheep’s wool rugs is the principal activity of the 15 women that make up the Bolivia Association that belongs to the Por-Mujer center in Villa Adela.

These women start early in the morning by preparing breakfast for their families. The majority of them are single mothers like Doña Pacesa, a widow with four children. She makes sweaters from alpaca wool and sells them at the 16th of July Fair in the city of El Alto. As is true for the other ladies, the small amount of income generated is barely enough to feed her family.

The Bolivia Association hopes to receive additional funds to buy raw materials (alpaca wool) and increase production. That way they will raise their income and reach their goal of having a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

El tejido de chompas de alpaca y alfombras en lana de oveja es la principal actividad de quincena de señoras agrupadas en la asociación “Bolivia” perteneciente al centro focal de Villa Adela de Pro-Mujer. Estas señoras empiezan su día en la madrugada para preparar los almuerzos para sus familias. La mayoría de ellas son jefes de familia, Como doña Pacesa que es viuda y tiene 4 hijos teje chompas en fibra de alpaca y las vende en la feria 16 de Julio de la ciudad de El Alto, los pocos ingresos que genera al igual que sus compañeras apenas les da para alimentar a sus familias. La asociación Bolivia espera acceder aun mayor crédito para comprar materia prima (fibra de camélidos) y aumentar su producción de esta manera mejoraría sus ingresos con el objetivo de mejorar su calidad de vida.

loans.use: Purchase raw material (wool)

loans.name: Las Peritas Group

texts.es:
The association known as “Las Peritas” has been a part of the Pro-Mujer family for a year and is a group consisting of 17 members who work very responsibly. The majority of the group works selling used clothing, something that is not very lucrative, which is what led them to look for other types of activities. Now they plan to work making different items like school uniforms, backpacks, shoes and baby clothes to be sold in different markets around the city. Those sales will be made with the help of their children who will work the stands selling until late at night.

They affirm that they need the capital to be able to buy raw materials and special machinery to make their products and thereby achieve a better quality. That way their businesses will be prosperous for them and their families.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

La asociación “Las Peritas" pertenece a la familia de Pro-Mujer hace 1 año, grupo formado por 17 miembros que trabajan con mucha responsabilidad. El grupo en gran parte se dedicaba a la venta de ropa usada, actividad que actualmente ya no es muy rentable lo que les llevo a buscar otro tipo de actividad. Ahora intentan dedicarse a la confección de distintos productos, como ser la confección en uniformes de escuela, mochilas, zapatos, y ropa de bebes, todos estos productos comercializados en las distintas feria de la ciudad, dichas ventas las realizan con la ayuda de sus hijos que deben quedarse en los puestos de venta hasta muy noche. Afirman que necesitan capital para poder comprar materia prima y maquinaria especial para la fabricación de sus productos de esta manera lograr una mejor calidad de estos y así sus negocios prosperen para el bien de ellos y sus familias..

loans.use: Purchase raw materials (fabric, leather, thread, etc.) and special machinery

loans.name: Chanroeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanroeun S. and her husband married in 1998. They have two sons and one daughter. One of her sons is in school and the other two stay at home. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about twelve kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Chanroeun has been selling groceries for 18 years. It’s a business skill she had learned from her mother. She buys grocery items from a market in Phnom Penh then sells them at her store in the village. Her husband is a wooden house constructor.

She is requesting a loan in the amount of $1000 to purchase grocery items for resale.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for resale.

loans.name: Vy

texts.en:
Mrs. Vy S. and her husband married in 1978. They have four sons and one daughter. Two of them are married and live outside the family house. The other three children include two of whom are employed full-time and the youngest one who attends school. The family lives in a Phnom Penh suburb.

Mrs. Vy has been selling groceries for the past ten years. She buys these groceries from the market in Phnom Penh for resale at her store. Her husband has been a motor taxi driver for fifteen years.

She is requesting a loan in the amount of $300 to purchase grocery items for resale.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for resale.

loans.name: Channa

texts.en:
Mrs. Channa V. and her husband married in 1987. They have six children; three sons and three daughters. One of their children is a factory worker. The other three children are in school and the two youngest stay at home. The family is a bout seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Channa and her husband have been selling groceries for six years. They bought grocery items from the market in Phnom Penh for resale at the front of their house.

Channa is requesting a loan in the amount of $700 to purchase grocery items for resale.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for resale.

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopahal S. and her husband married in 1999. They have two sons, one of whom is in school. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Sophal has been a weaver for eleven years. It’s a skill she learned from her aunt. She sells her finished products to the middle man in the village who sells them in Phnom Penh. Apart from weaving, Sophal also sells pork in the village market in the mornings. She has been doing this business for eight years. Her husband is a silk weaver as well.

She is requesting a loan in the amount of $200 to purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving

loans.name: Sum

texts.en:
Mrs. Sum S. is widow with four children; one son and three daughters. Two of her children married and live in the family house while the other two children are in school. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Sum has been a silk weaver since she was young. She picked up this skill from her parents. She sells her finished product to the middle man in the village who will take it to sell in Phnom Penh.

She is requesting a loan in the amount of $200 to purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving

loans.name: Oeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Oeun Y. and her husband married in 1979. They have seven children - two sons and five daughters. Two of their daughters are married and live outside the family home and the other three daughters are garment factory workers. Their two sons are in school. The family is about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Oeun has been selling fruit for two years. She buys mangoes and sapodillas from a farmer in the village, then puts them up for resale at a market in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a carpenter for twenty years.

Mrs. Oeun is requesting a loan in the amount of $1000 to purchase fruit for resale and fill in the land around the house.

loans.use: To purchase fruit for resale and fill in the land around the house

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophal C. and her husband married in 2005. They have one young son. The family is about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Sophal has been selling dessert for nine years. She sells the dessert in front of her house. Her husband has been a construction worker for the past four years. Now, he wants to create another business selling ice cream by motorbike around the village.

Mrs. Sophal is requesting a loan in the amount of $700 to purchase a motorbike for selling ice cream.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for selling ice cream

loans.name: Vibol

texts.en:
Mr. Vibol N. and his wife married in 2003. They have two daughters who are still young so they stay at home. The family lives on an island on Mekong River about twelve kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mr. Vibol has been a wooden house constructor for three years. It’s a skill he learned from his neighbor. He runs his business in the village and near by provinces. His wife is a silk weaver.

Mr. Vibol is requesting a loan in the amount of $700 to purchase a construction crane for his business.

loans.use: To purchase a construction crane.

loans.name: Dy

texts.en:
Mrs. Dy Choen and her husband married in 1990. Together, they have six sons; her oldest son is a wooden house constructor. The family lives on an island on Mekong River about twelve kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Dy has been in the business of selling groceries for six years. She buys grocery items from a market in Phnom Penh for resale at her shop in front of the house. Her husband serves as a driver for a transportation company.

Mrs. Dy is requesting a loan in the amount of $500 to purchase a construction crane for her son’s business.

loans.use: To purchase a construction crane for her son.

loans.name: Voun

texts.en:
Mr. Voun C. and his wife married in 1986. They have six children; three daughters and three sons. Two of their children are employed full-time and the other three are in school. The youngest one stays at home. The family lives about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mr. Voun has been fishing for 28 years. He fishes from his village then sells them in Prek Pnao Market. Meanwhile, his wife stays at home to take care of the children.

He is requesting a loan in the amount of $400 to purchase fishing nets and lotus plants.

loans.use: To purchase fishing net and planting lotus.

loans.name: Salelologa A Centre - Group 2

texts.en:
While SaleL., the capital village of Savaii Island, is largely semi-urbanized, its outlying areas are still agricultural. The SaleL. A Centre is located in a largely agricultural area and the people in the community still subsist on farming and vegetable gardening.

For this group, these are their first loans from SPBD. They all undertook 4 weeks of training on managing a business, maintained a savings account, and then passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

Peneueta Pipi O., 36, has 5 children and is married to a taxi driver. She has over 2 years of experience in sewing and running a shop. She will use her loan to purchase a sewing machine, scissors, petrol, needles, material, and thread. At her shop, she will sell t-shirts, puletasis (dresses), and snacks.

Sesilia T., 30, is married with 3 children. She has over 5 years experience running a pig farm. With her loan, she will purchase 6 pigs, a fence, and pig feed. She hopes to earn 150 Tala (~60 USD) net cash flow per week.

Sina N., 51, is widowed and has 5 children. She sells assorted goods at the SaleL. market 6 days per week. With her loan, she will purchase sugar, rice, flour, potatoes, cabbage, dishes, and bowls.

loans.use: Purchase a sewing machine, scissors, needles, material, etc

loans.name: Ni Wayan Winarti

texts.id:
Ni Wayan Winarti is a homemaker who is assiduous in working. Winarti opens a convenient kiosk in front of her house, and sells basic food ingredients and everyday’s supplies. Winarti opens her kiosk from 9 am until 10 pm for her customers, who live in her neighborhood. Everyday, Winarti buys her inventory from a local market using a motorcycle. Winarti earns from $2.50 to $3.50 daily. From this income and her husband’s as a farmer, they can meet their family’s needs and pays for their child’s 7th grade school tuition. With her healthy and productive family situation, Winarti hopes that the loan she is requesting through DINARI can help expand her business.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Joan, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Wayan Winarti adalah seorang ibu rumah tangga yang sangat tekun dalam bekerja. Winarti membuka warung di tempat tinggalnya yang menjual bahan makanan dan kebutuhan sehari-hari. Winarti mulai berjualan dari pukul 09.00 pagi hingga pukul 10.00 malam dimana para pelanggannya adalah warga di sekitar tempat tinggalnya. Setiap pagi Winarti membeli kebutuhan dan kelengkapan warungnya di pasar terdekat dengan menggunakan sepeda motor. Keuntungan yang diperoleh Winarti setiap hari sekitar Rp 25.000,- sampai Rp 35.000,-. Dari hasil jualannya dan dibantu oleh suaminya yang bekerja di sawah sebagai petani, Winarti mampu mencukupi kebutuhan keluarganya dan sanggup menyekolahkan anaknya sampai kelas 1 SMP. Dengan keadaan keluarganya yang sehat dan masih produktif diharapkan pinjaman modal dari DINARI akan membantu mengembangkan usaha dari Winarti.

loans.use: To increase business capital

loans.name: Ni Putu Sri Wiriani

texts.id:
It is hard to find ready-to-eat entrees and snacks sellers in the Brawantangi village. Therefore, Ni Putu Sri Wiriani became a a travelling food seller, selling ready-to-eat entrees, snacks and various vegetables. Every morning, Sri buys her inventory from the individuals, who cook the food, and from her local market. Her customers mostly live in her neighborhood. They appreciate Sri’s service because they do not have to go to the market themselves to buy and prepare their meals. Sri earns around $2.50 - $5 profits daily. From this income and her husband’s as a farmer, they can support their daily needs, including their child’s first grade tuition. With the loan through DINARI, Sri is hopeful that she can expand her business.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Joan, Kiva volunteer.

Di dusun Brawantangi sangat jarang ditemui penjual lauk pauk dan kue serta makanan lainnya yang sudah siap disantap. Oleh karena itu Ni Putu Sri Wiriani berinisiatif untuk menjadi pedagang keliling yang menjual lauk pauk, kue dan berbagai macam sayuran yang sudah jadi. Setiap pagi Sri membeli bahan dagangannya dari orang yang sudah membuatkan dan ada pula yang dibeli di pasar. Langganan Sri umumnya berada di sekitar dusun tempat tinggalnya. Kebanyakan dari para pelanggannya merasa tertolong dengan dagang keliling yang ditekuni Sri karena tidak perlu harus ke pasar untuk membeli bahan makanan. Keuntungan perhari yang di dapat oleh Sri sekitar Rp. 25.000,- sampai Rp. 50.000,-. Dari keuntungan dagang keliling ini bersama suaminya yang bekerja sebagi petani, Sri mampu membiayai kebutuhan sehari-hari keluarganya, serta mampu memenuhi keperluan anaknya yang masih duduk di bangku SD kelas 1. Dengan adanya pinjaman dari DINARI maka besar harapan Sri akan mampu meningkatkan jumlah dagangannnya.

loans.use: To increase business capital

loans.name: Ni Putu Sulastri

texts.id:
Living in the Brawantangi village, Ni Putu Sulastri opens a tailor and embroidery business. She and her husband, who is a farmer, live in their own house. Ni Putu Sulastri is requesting a loan through DINARI to buy an additional sewing machine in her business facility. With $15 to $20 weekly profit, Ni Putu Sulastri can support her child, who is in first grade, as well as fulfilling her daily needs. Her husband helps her with her business, and their clean and orderly house helps her family live happily.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Joan, Kiva volunteer.

Bertempat tinggal didusun brawantangi Ni Putu sulastri membuka usaha menjahit baju dan bordir. Bersama dengan suaminya yang seorang petani, keluarga ini menempati sebuah rumah milik sendiri. Dengan mengajukan pinjaman ke DINARI. Ni Putu Sulastri ingin membeli sebuah mesin jahit lagi untuk menambah fasilitas usahanya. Dengan pemasukan Rp.150.000.- s/d 200.000 / minggu, Ni Putu Sulastri bisa membiayai anaknya yang duduk di kelas satu SD juga bisa memenuhi kebutuhan sehari-hari. Dalam menjalankan usahanya Ni Putu Sulastri dibantu oleh suaminya. Keadaan rumah yang bersih dan tanaman yang teratur membuat keluarganya harmonis. By:Desy

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Ni Ketut Sriati

texts.id:
Ni Ketut Sriati is a kiosk owner, who opens her business in front of her own house. She lives with her husband, I Putu Sutama, and their two elementary-school-age children in the Brawantangi village, West Bali. Sriati is requesting a loan through DINARI with hopes that she can increate her business capital. With a $3 daily profit, Sriati opens her kiosk from 9 am to 8 pm. She is optimistic that her business will grow and be successful.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Joan, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Ketut Sriati adalah seorang pedagang yang membuka usahanya dengan berjualan disebuah warung yang letaknya berada didepan rumahnya sendiri. Bersama dengan suaminya, I Putu Sutama tinggal didusun Brawantangi, Bali Barat bersama kedua anaknya yang masih duduk dibangku sekolah dasar. Sriati mengajukan permohonan pinjaman ke Dinari. Sriati berharap bisa mendapatkan pinjaman untuk meningkatkan usahanya. Dengan pendapatan Rp. 30.000.- / hari, Sriati membuka warungnya dari jam 9 pagi hingga jam 8 malam. Sriati optimis usahanya akan maju dan sukses.

loans.use: To increase business capital

loans.name: Nen

texts.en:
Mrs. Nen N., a 58-year-old widow, makes about $4 as a seamstress from her home in Kork Chrobok Village, Phnom Penh City. N. has one married daughter, whose her husband is a security guard in a garment factory.

N. requests a loan of $500 to purchase a motorcycle so her son-in-law can commute to work more easily.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle so her son-in-law can commute to work more easily.

loans.name: Thi Thao

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Thao is 38 years old. Her husband is a construction worker, and her three children are going to school and working. Mrs. Thao stays at home and raises pigs. Her average monthly income is about 100,000 to 200,000 VND (about 6USD-13USD). She wants to borrow 2,006,000 VND (which is equivalent to 125USD) to buy bran for her pigs. Mrs. Thao is very interested in participating in the program for long. Mrs. Chu Thi Luong is 27 years old. She wants to borrow 2,006,000 VND (which is equivalent to 125USD) to buy fertilizers and piglets. Mrs. N. Thi Nguyen is 28 years old. She wants to borrow 2,006,000 VND (which is equivalent to 125USD) to buy bran for her pigs and fertilizers. Mrs. N. Thi Hien is 34 years old. She wants to borrow 2,006,000 VND (which is equivalent to 125USD) to buy bran for her pigs. Mrs. N. Thi Ha is 22 years old. She wants to borrow 2,006,000 VND (which is equivalent to 125USD) to buy piglets.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Ngô Thị Thảo (MS: 09050068) năm nay 38 tuổi, chồng làm thợ xây, có 3 con đang đi học và đi làm. Chị Thảo ở nhà chăn nuôi lợn, thu nhập trung bình của gia đình khoảng 100.000 ->200.000 VNĐ một tuần. Chị vay 2.006.000 VNĐ để thêm vốn mua cám cho lợn. Chi rất muốn được tham gia lâu dài với trương trình. Chị Chu Thị Lương (MS: 09050069) năm nay 27 tuổi.Chị vay 2.006.000 VNĐ để mua phân bón lúa và thêm vốn mua lợn giống. Chị Ngô Thị Nguyên (MS: 09050070) năm nay 28 tuổi. Chị vay 2.006.000 VNĐ để thêm vốn mua cám cho lợn và mua phân bón lúa. Chị Ngô Thị Hiền (MS: 06050071) năm nay 34 tuổi. Chị vay 2.006.000 VNĐ để mua cám cho lợn. Chị Ngô Thị Hà (MS: 09050072) năm nay 22 tuổi. Chị vay 2.006.000 VNĐ để thêm vốn mua lợn giống.

loans.use: Vay vốn để chăn nuôi và trồng rau.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for SEDA - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Isnaini

texts.id:
Despite an increasing cost for basic needs, Mrs. Isnanini is determined to continue selling fried snacks. She starts her day at 5 am by frying bananas, cassavas and jewel yams. By 7 am, she is ready to distribute her fried snacks to the food kiosks around her house. This 35-year-old mother of two usually buys her ingredients in the late afternoon at the Badung market either by public transporation or by a motorcycle driven by her husband. Her business profit is saved up for her two children’s educational needs. Mrs. Isnanini hopes to use this loan to increase her business capital.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Joan, Kiva volunteer.

Walaupun sembako harganya mahal dan terus menanjak, namun hal itu tidak mengubah niat Ibu Isnanini untuk menekuni usaha jual gorengan. Setiap hari ia harus bangun pukul 05.00 pagi dan mulai menggoreng pisang, ketela pohon dan ubi jalar. Pukul 07.00 pagi ia sudah siap mengirim gorengannya ke warung-warung disekitar rumahnya. Ibu berusia 35 tahun dengan 2 (dua) anak ini biasanya belanja bahan-bahan dagangannya pada sore hari dipasar Badung dengan naik angkot dan kadang diantar oleh suaminya menggunakan sepeda motor. Dari keuntungan usahanya ia bisa menabung untuk membiayai pendidikan kedua anaknya. Ibu Isnanini berharap dari pinjaman kali ini bisa dijadikan sebagai tambahan modal usaha.

loans.use: To increase business capital

loans.name: Sukati

texts.id:
Sukati with her family live in a Rp 160,000/month rented room at Jl. Mertasari, Gang Laksamana Suwung Kangin. In front of the room, she built a booth to sell ice, "gado-gado" (vegetable salad) and other daily needs. Her customers are those who live around her rented room. The income earned from the sales is used for financing her children tuition fee, which are now in junior high school.

Sukati proposed to use the loan to add the capital so that she could increase the variation of the goods sold in her booth. In running the business, Sukati is assisted by her husband. They use their motorcycle to go to the nearest market to purchase the goods to be sold.

Translated from Indonesian by Hestyana, Kiva Volunteer.

Sukati saat ini tinggal di Jl.Mertasari, Gang Laksamana Suwung Kangin, dengan mengontrak sebuah kamar dengan Rp.160.000/bulan. Dia tinggal bersama keluarganya dan sekarang keadaan mereka sehat. Didepan terasnya dibuat sebuah warung kecil unutk berjualan es, gadoogado dan kebutuhan sembako lainnya. Para pelanggannya adalah mereka yang tinggal disekitar tempat kostnya. Dari hasil usahanya klien yang dibantu juga oleh suaminya bisa menyekolahkan anaknya sampai SMP. Dari pinjaman kali ini klien berharap bisa dijadikan sebagai tambahan modal usaha untuk memperbanyak jenis jualan diwarungnya sehingga warung sembako miliknya menjadi lebih lengkap. Ibu Sukati memiliki sepeda motor yang biasanya dipergunakan sebagai alat transportasi untuk belanja kebutuhan sembako dipasar terdekat.

loans.use: To increase sales value

loans.name: Mohammad Ashraf

texts.en: Mohammad Ashraf lives in district 4 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He has a photo shop and he has good experience in his business. He has already successfully completed his first cycle loan and expanded his stock. Still, he wants to further expand his business with full success, so now he has requested his second cycle loan to enlarge his shop so as to attract more customers and make good income to help his family. He is happy with this process of small loans in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To expand his shop

loans.name: Sri

texts.id:
Sri Widiyati lives in Jl.Palapa XI No 5 Denpasar together with her husband and their 3 children. They rented the land for Rp.1.000.000.- a year and build their own building on it. Their home is a simple and clean one.

Sri Widiyati and her husband run a laundry business since 2003. Their customers are those who live around Jl.Palapa. They only do laundry business activities on the afternoon, because they should run their other business: selling underwear in Batam Market, Kendal Suwung, in the morning until 12.00 a.m. Sri uses a motorcycle as her daily vehicle.

Translated from Indonesian by Hestyana, Kiva Volunteer.

Sri Widiyati tinggal di Jl.Palapa XI No 5 denpasar dengan mengontrak tanah senilai Rp.1.000.000.- pertahun dan membuat bangunan sendiri diatasnya sebagai tempat tinggal bersama suami dan ketiga anaknya. Rumahnya cukup sederhana dan bersih. Usaha laundrynya sendiri sudah dimulai sekitar tahun 2003 dan pelanggannya kebanyakan adalah penduduk sekitar Jl.Palapa. Usaha laundry biasanya ditekuni pada siang hari sebab pada pagi harinya Ibu Sri W. mempunyai usaha menjual pakaian dalam di Pasar Batam Kendal Suwung. Usaha jual pakaiannya biasanya dari pagi sampai jam 12.00. Sebagai alat transportasi sehari-hari Ibu Sri menggunakan sepeda motor.

loans.use: To increase capital

loans.name: Badrul

texts.id:
Badrul M. (25 years old) lives in a rented room in Jl.Bedahulu with her wife and their 2 children. To support the family, Badrul should work hard. Everyday, he starts to walk and collect trash from 05.00 a.m., has a little rest at noon, and continues his activity until afternoon. His wife usually helps him to sort the trash and classify them. The trash is usually sold within 3 days.

Badrul wishes to earn the loan, so that he would be able to purchase second-hands goods from his neighbors and resell them.

Translated from Indonesian by Hestyana, Kiva Volunteer.

Badrul M. (25 th) tinggal di Jl.Bedahulu dengan menyewa sebuah kamar bersama istri dan 2 (dua) orang anaknya. Keadaan keluarganya sehat, tetapi karena harus membiayai anaknya yang masih sekolah, setiap hari Badrul harus bekerja keras mulai pukul 05.00 pagi dengan berkeliling mencari barang-barang bekas hingga tengah hari dan kembali melakukan aktifitas yang sama pada sore harinya. Biasanya dia dibantu oleh istrinya, tetapi istrinya hanya membantu menyortir atau memilah barang yang masih bagus dan yang tidak. Hasil yang didapat biasanya sudah dijual dalam jangka waktu 3 (tiga) hari. Badrul berharap dengan bantuan pinjaman kali ini dia bisa membeli barang-barang bekas milik warga sekitarnya dan kemudian menjualnya kembali.

loans.use: As the capital to purchase second-hands goods to be rsold

loans.name: Mwanaidi

texts.en: Mwanaidi is 39 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 12 and 3 years old. She and her husband also take care of 1 other person, who is 60 years old. Mwanaidi owns a small cafe that she started in 2008. Every day, she works from 8am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Veronica's Sele Bosi Group

texts.en:
Veronica is 38 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 15,10 and 2 years old. She and her husband also take care of 2 other people, ages 70 and 68 years old. Veronica owns a small grocery, which she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 8am to 1pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more comodities for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who sell fish and charcoal, and work as a waitress.

loans.use: To buy more comodities for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Amina's Sele Bosi Group

texts.en:
Amina is 35 years old and is a married woman with 1child, age 15 years old. She and her husband also take care of 2 other people, ages 40 and 50 years old. Amina owns a small grocery store that she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 11am to 1pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Amina S., who sells food.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Mariam's Nguvumali E Group

texts.en:
Mariam is 28 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 6 and 2 years old. She and her husband also take care of 2 other people, ages 60 and 50 years old. Mariam owns a small grocery store that she started in 2000. Every day, she works from 11am to 11pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Zaina, who has a grocery store.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Mikali

texts.en: Mikali is a married woman with 3 children, ages 18,13, and 12 years old. She and her husband also take care of 2 other people, both of whom are 60 years old. Mikali owns a small stock of animals, which she started in 2005. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food for her animals.

loans.use: To buy food for her animals

loans.name: Nakazadde Women's Group

texts.en:
Selina is the treasurer of Nakazadde Women’s group in Lugazi town. The 53-year-old is a single mother of 6 children and cares for 4 grandchildren in her house. She separated from her husband many years ago but she has managed to raise her children through her fish selling business in Lugazi Central market which she has been running for 23 solid years. She buys the fish from Kiyindi Landing Site usually on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday, and she is not regretting the steps she took. She also supplies small silvery fish to chicken mash stores in Lugazi and this has increased her savings.

Selina wants to start a shop at her home since she is aging, as well as building houses for rent and above all, she looks forward to sending her remaining 2 school-going children to a higher level since one is in Senior 6 while the other is in Senior 3. She has planned to buy more fish if given the loan, with a view to increasing her savings so that she can start with her construction plans soon.

loans.use: buy more dry fish for re-sale

loans.name: Jumat B.

texts.id:
Jumat B.R. (49 years old) has 2 children. His oldest son has passed away, and his second one has got married. Now he only lives with his wife in Jl. Bedahulu. Jumat B.R. is a hard worker. He starts collecting trash from 05.00 a.m., has a little rest at noon, and continues his activity until afternoon. His wife usually helps him to sort the trash, classify those, separate those which are still good and those which are not. They usually sell the sorted trash within 3 days, and earn around Rp.15.000/day.

Jumat B.R. expects with the loan he proposes, he would be able to purchase second-hands goods from his surrounding neighbors and sell them.

Translated from Indonesian by Hestyana, Kiva Volunteer.

Jumat B.R. (49 th) memiliki 2 (dua) orang anak dan bertempat tinggal di Jl.Bedahulu. Anaknya yang sulung telah meninggal duania, sedangkan anaknya yang ke_2 sudah menikah. Ia sekarang tinggal beserta istrinya. Setiap hari Jumat harus bekerja keras mulai pukul 05.00 pagi dengan berkeliling mencari barang-barang bekas hingga tengah hari dan kembali melakukan aktifitas yang sama pada sore harinya. Biasanya dia dibantu oleh istrinya, tetapi istrinya hanya membantu menyortir atau memilah barang yang masih bagus dan yang tidak. Hasil yang didapat biasanya sudah dijual dalam jangka waktu 3 (tiga) hari dan keuntungannya bisa sekitar Rp.15.000/hari. Jumat berharap dengan bantuan pinjaman kali ini dia bisa membeli barang-barang bekas milik warga sekitarnya dan kemudian menjualnya kembali.

loans.use: To purchase second-hand goods to be sold

loans.name: Patience

texts.en:
Patience is thirty-two years old and the mother of one child. She has been selling boiled eggs and pepper for the past nine years. She travels throughout her neighborhood selling her eggs.

She wants to use her new loan to buy more crates of eggs. This will enable her supply caterers and increase her income. She also wants to rent a store to keep the eggs. She currently keeps the eggs in her bedroom.

She a member of the group called May Flower. Members guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more eggs to sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sinapi Aba Trust (SAT) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Lamiah

texts.id:
Lamiah lives in Jl.Resimuka. She sews beads sandals everyday. With sewing machine, beads, shells and beads plate, she runs the business well that she is able to afford daily family needs. But now, the price of raw materials is increasing and create difficulties to her. Therefore, she whishes to earn loan to add the capital of her business.

Translated from Indonesian by Hestyana, Kiva Volunteer.

Bertempat tinggal di Jl.Resimuka, Ibu Lamiah sehari-harinya bekerja menjahit sandal mote. Dengan bermodalkan mesin jahit, manik-manik, kerang-kerangan dan piringan mote, usaha yang dijalani Ibu Lamiah cukup lancar dan bisa untuk membiayai kebutuhan kelarga sehari-hari. Tetapi karena sekarang ini bahan-bahan baku untuk pembuatan sandal mote terus meningkat, Ibu Lamiah sangat kesulitan. Oleh karena itu Ibu Lamiah sangat berharap bantuan pinjaman kali ini bisa dijadikan sebagai tambahan modal usahanya.

loans.use: To increase capital

loans.name: Salamatu

texts.en:
Salamatu is married and has two children who are in school. She has been selling roasted groundnuts and maize for the past five years. Every two weeks, she travels to the northern part of Ghana to purchase the nuts and the maize.

Salamatu wants to use her new loan to buy more bags of maize and groundnuts to reduce her frequent travels to the north and also to avoid price hikes during the lean season.

She a member of the group called Baa Meyi. The group members guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

In the photo, Salamatu carrying her roasted groundnuts.

loans.use: To buy more groundnuts and maize.

loans.name: Halima's Gofu Juu Shule. Group

texts.en: Halima is a married woman with one child, age three years old. She and her husband also take care of two other people, ages 60 and 50 years old. Halima sells fruit through a business she started in 2008. Everyday, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.  Halima now hopes for a loan of $400 to buy more fruit for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Amina and Mwanakombo, who also have businesses dealing in fruits and vegetables.

loans.use: To buy more fruits for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Sauda's Kisosora Utofu Group

texts.en: Sauda is a married woman with six children. She and her husband also take care of one other 65 year old person. Sauda is a livestock owner, and has been since 2005. Everyday, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business. She now hopes for a loan of $425 to buy more fodder for her animals. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Fatuma and Amina, who have businesses dealing in the vending of food items.

loans.use: To buy more fodder for her animals.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Fawzia

texts.en:
Fawzia is thirty-four years old and the mother of three children. The children are currently in school. She has a grocery store where she sells a variety of products, such as toiletries, baby foods, canned drinks, and pomades.

Fawzia wants to use her loan to buy more cartons of baby foods, boxes of diapers, and bags of rice and sugar

.

She is a member of the group called May Flower. Group members guarantee for each other as social collateral in repaying the loan.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of baby foods, boxes of diapers, bags of rice and sugar.

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 40 years old. He has three children. His elderly mother and young sister are living with him in a rented house. His children are studying in school, and his sister is studying in university. He has a sewing shop, and he applied to borrow $1200 to purchase a new sewing machine and new fabric to make more clothes to sell. He also wants to paint the shop in order to increase his income and save for a better life for his family.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Purchase a new sewing machine and new fabric

loans.name: Patience

texts.en:
Patience is fifty-five years old and the mother of three children. Two the children are in school. She has been selling onions, dry crabs, shrimp, and herring in her community for the past six years.

She wants to use her new loan to buy more onions and shrimp from Keta, a city in the eastern part of Ghana.

Patience is a member of the group called Destiny. Members of the group guarantee social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more onions and shrimp

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sinapi Aba Trust (SAT) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Mwanamkasi

texts.en: Mwanamkasi is 39 years old and is married with four children. She and her husband also take care of two other people, who are both 70 years old. Mwanamkasi is a shoe seller through a business she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.  She now hopes for a loan of $150 to buy more shoes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more shoes for her business.

loans.name: Bismark

texts.en:
Bismark is forty-four years old, married, and the father of two children. The children are currently in school. Bismark is a caterer. He has been preparing local dishes, such as rice balls, banku, and boiled yams in his community for the past three years.

He wants to use his new loan to add new local dishes such as fufu and konkonte, and to expand his eating place.

He a member of the group called Shepherd. Members of the group use social collateral as a guarantee for repaying the loan.

Bismark, his wife (first on the left), and children are shown in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more bags of maize, bags of rice, vegetables, bags of cassava,etc.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sinapi Aba Trust (SAT) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Lis

texts.id:
Lis H. lives together happily with her husband and their only child in Jl. Palapa XIV Blok C-9/17 Suwung Kangin. She runs a merchandising business, i.e. selling clothes door-to-door, which has been started since 10 years ago. The goods she sell are usually boarded from Surabaya and Jakarta, which then sold around Tempe Lake. She sells the goods with daily installment.

Lis H. is assisted by a helper. She uses motorcycle to go from her house to the place where she sells her goods, which is not too far, only 15' motor riding. Lis H. wishes that she would be able to increase the sales value of her merchandises with the loan she expects to earn. She is sure that her business is very promising.

Translated from Indonesian by Hestyana, Kiva Volunteer.

Lis H. beserta suami dan seorang anaknya tinggal di Jl.palapa XIV Blok C-9/17 Suwung Kangin. Keadaan keluarganya sehat. Lis Kartini mulai menekuni usahanya sekitar 10 tahun yang lalu dan biasanya barang-barangnya didatangkan dari Surabaya dan Jakarta lalu kemudian dengan bantuan seorang tenaga kerjanya dia menjualnya di sekitar Danau Tempe. Biasanya baju dijual dengan cara kredit dan biasanya pembayarannya menggunakan sistem angsuran harian. Jarak antara rumah dan tempat usahanya tidak terlalu jauh, sekitar 15 menit kalau ditempuh menggunakan sepeda motor. Sepeda motor itulah yang biasanya digunakan Lis Kartini untuk memasarkan barang jualannya. Lis Kartini berharap dari pinjaman kali ini dia bisa menambah omset penjualannya karena menurutnya usaha ini sangat menjanjikan.

loans.use: To increase the capital to increase sales value

loans.name: Halima's Shukrani Group

texts.en: Halima is 40 years old and is married with 5 children, ages 15-22 years old. She and her husband also take care of two other children, ages 5 and 18 years old. Halima is a fish seller through a business she started in 2003. Everyday, she works from 9am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $130 from her sales.  She now hopes for a loan of $275 to buy more fish for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Mwanahamadi, who has a business dealing in charcoal and firewood  sales.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Fati

texts.en:
Fati is thirty years old and she has three children. The children are currently in school. Fati has been preparing and selling banku, boiled yams, and cooked rice for the past three years.

She wants to use her new loan to buy more fresh yams, bags of rice, bags of beans, and gallons of vegetable oil for her dishes.

Fati is a member of the group called May Flower. Group members exert peer pressure as social collateral in repaying the loan.

loans.use: To buy more fresh yams, maize, rice, and vegetables, etc.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sinapi Aba Trust (SAT) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Cheka's Mwanzo Mgumu Group

texts.en: Cheka is 28 years old and is married with 2 children, ages 12 and 8 years old. She and her husband also take care of another child, who is 16 years old. Cheka is charcoal and firewood seller through a business she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.  She now hopes for a loan of $650 to buy more charcoal and firewood for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Anjelina, Mwanamkasi, Halima and Marina, who have businesses dealing in cloth sales and fish sales.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Kijoli's Mwanzo Mgumu Group

texts.en: Kijoli is 23 years old and is married with one child, age 3 years old. She and her husband also take care of one other person, age 30 years old. Kijoli is a fish seller through a business she started in 2000. Everyday, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.  She now hopes for a loan of $275 to buy more fish for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Magreth, who has business dealing in charcoal and firewood sales.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business.

loans.name: Tatu's Rajabu Group

texts.en: Tatu is 29 years old and is a married woman with three children, ages 14,12 and 10 years old. Tatu is a cloth seller through the business she started in 2008. Everyday, she works from 9am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $20 from her sales.  She now hopes for a loan of $275 to buy more cloth for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Maria, who has business dealing in fish sales.

loans.use: To buy more cloth for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Halima

texts.en: Halima is 36 years old and is married woman with four children, ages 19,16,11 and 4 years old. She and her husband also take care of one other person, age 35  years old. Halima owns a small food store, which she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 6am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.  She now hopes for a loan of $150 to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Sam Ath

texts.en: Mrs. Sam Ath C. is a wedding chef in the Prey Tachap Village of the Kampong Speu Province. She is 36 years old, and she is the mother of five children. Three of her children attend school, while the other two children are still too young to work and/or study. Her husband, Rin Kheav, pictured on the right of the photo, is a poultry breeder in the village. Mrs. Sam Ath C. spends her family's limited income on her children’s education and other family expenses. She already received one loan from AMK to purchase groceries to sell, and she proudly claims that her repayments were always made on time. Last June, her husband contracted a serious disease, hemiplegia, which caused him to be hospitalized and ultimately cost the family approximately $1,000. Fortunately, he is currently in good health, and he is able to work once again. Presently, Mrs. Sam Ath Chch is seeking a loan to build a chicken stall in the back yard.

loans.use: To construct a chicken stall in the family's back yard.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is thirty-four years old and the mother of three children. Two of her children are in school. Margaret has been selling items like diapers, bedspreads, and baby dresses for the past seven years.

She wants to use her new loan to buy more diapers, napkins, bed spreads and to buy containers to secure her products from theft and weather as she peddles them from place to place.

Margaret is a member of the group called Shepherd. Members guarantee for each other as social collateral in repaying the loan.

loans.use: To  buy more boxes of diapers, dresses, napkins, etc

loans.name: Zawadi

texts.en: Zawadi is married woman with five children.  Zawadi is a fish seller through a business she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 7am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.  She now hopes for a loan of $150 to buy more fish for her business.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity is thirty-three years old and the mother of three children. Two of her children are currently in school. She has been selling frozen products like fish, chicken and beef, and charcoal for the past year. Charity travels from place to place selling frozen products in the mornings and evenings.

She wants to use her new loan to buy more frozen products and bags of charcoal.

Charity is a member of the group called Shepherd. Members agree to use peer pressure on each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and frozen products like fish and chicken

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sinapi Aba Trust (SAT) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Salima's Kusaidiana Group

texts.en: Salima is 30 years old and is a married woman. Salima is a cloth seller with a business she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from sales.  She now hopes for a loan of $775 to buy more cloth for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in fish sales, charcoal and firewood sales, cloth sales and shop management.

loans.use: To buy more cloth for her business.

loans.name: Veronica's Usagara Muheza Group

texts.en: Veronica is 21 years old and is a single woman.  She works as a  cloth seller through a business she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $170 from her sales.  She now hopes for a loan of $275 to buy more cloth for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Bahati, who also has  business dealing in cloth sales.

loans.use: To buy more cloth for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Thach

texts.en: Mrs. Thach S. is a 38-year-old vegetable seller in the local village, Paing L’vea, which is located in the Kampong Speu Province. She has three children who are all enrolled in school. Her husband, Oun Chhem, pictured on the right of the photo, is a pig breeder. The family spends its limited income on pig food, education (for the children), and other such expenses. She already received one loan from AMK, and with the loan proceeds she purchased pigs and built the pigs’ stall next to her house. With respect to the first loan she received from AMK, she proudly claims that her repayments were always made in a timely manner. Currently, she is seeking a loan to be able to buy more vegetables to sell in the village.

loans.use: To purchase additional vegetables to sell at the local village.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is forty-six years old, a widow and the mother of three children. All of her children are currently in school. She has been selling fresh eggs to bakers, caterers, and cooks for the past two years.

Mary buys the eggs from a local farm. She wants to use her loan to buy more crates of eggs so that she can supply to food vendors, caterers, cooks, and matrons.

She is a member of the group called Destiny. Members of the group use peer pressure as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more crates of eggs.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sinapi Aba Trust (SAT) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort is fifty-five years old and the mother of four children. She buys frozen fish from Tema, a city in southeastern Ghana, and smokes the fish on a local oven made of clay. She then travels to Volta region to sell the fish.

Comfort wants to use her new loan to buy more fish from Tema Harbour for smoking to meet her customers' needs.

She is a member of the group called May Flower. Members guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sinapi Aba Trust (SAT) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Ayi

texts.en:
Ayi is a divorced mother with two children. She is forty-three years old and prepares and has been selling kenkey, a meal prepared from milled maize, for the past thirty years.

Ayi wants to use her loan to purchase more bags of maize, firewood and plantain leaves to rap the kenkey.

She is a member of the group called May Flower. The group uses peer pressure as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more maize, firewood and plantain leaves.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sinapi Aba Trust (SAT) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is twenty-five years old. She sells body creams, deodorant, hair creams, combs, hair conditioners, shampoos, etc in her community.

She wants to use her loan to buy more products to expand her operations.

Monica is a member of the group called “Awurade Ye” (meaning God is good). Members of the group agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more hair cream, artificial hair, body creams, etc.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence has sold palm oil, plantains, fresh yams, cocoyams, etc. for the past thirty years. She is forty two years old, married and has six children. The oil business was not doing well and therefore she decided to sell foodstuffs to supplement her income.

Florence has realized that foodstuffs have higher demand and therefore wants to use her new loan to buy more tubers of yam, sacks of cocoyam, plantains, etc for good sales to increase her income. She is a member of the group called Maranatha. Members of the group exert peer pressure on each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: Florence would like to buy more tubers of fresh yams, plantain, palm oil, etc.

loans.name: Kate

texts.en:
Kate is forty eight years old and the mother of four children who are all in school. She has been cooking tomato stew for school children and her community members for the past two years. She wants to use her loan to buy more bags of rice, tomatoes and spices to cook for the children and the community.

Kate is a member of the group called Tree of Life. Group members exert peer pressure on members as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: Kate would like to buy more bags of rice, spices and vegetables.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en: Halima is 25 years old and is a single  woman with one child, age 10 years old. Halima is a fish exporter with a business she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 6am to 6pm at her shop and can earn a monthly profit of about $170 from her sales.  Halima now hopes for a loan of $175 to buy more fish for her business.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Mwanamboto's Mwanzo Mgumu Group

texts.en: Mwanamboto is 40  years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 25 and 15 years old. She and her husband also take care of one other person, who is 25 years old.
