Doña Carmen esta solicitando el crédito para invertirlos en mejoras en su casa y de esa manera tener mayor comodidad en su hogar.

loans.use: To make repairs in her home.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for AFODENIC - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Silverio

texts.es:
Silverio is a 54 year old man. He sells grains, travelling throughout different parts of the country in order to buy his products cheaper, which he then sells back home to the clients that requested his products. His wife helps him with the daily expenses. She sells tortillas in her neighborhood. Silverio has been in this business for 15 years, and he is a very hardworking man. He wants to have his own store where he can sell his products and in that way formalize his business. He will use the loan to buy grains for his business.

Translated from Spanish by Samantha, Kiva volunteer.

El Señor Silverio es casado, tiene 54 años, se dedica a la venta de granos básicos, viaja a los diferentes departamentos de nuestro país para buscar sus productos y de esa manera comprarlos más baratos, para luego venderlos a los clientes que le encargaron sus productos. Su esposa lo apoya con los gastos de la casa, la señora se dedica a la venta de tortillas las cuales las ofrece en su barrio. Don Silverio tiene 15 años de dedicarse a este negocio, es un hombre negociante y muy trabajador, espera en un futuro tener un puesto de venta fijo donde pueda ofrecer sus productos y de esa manera establecerse de forma más formal. El préstamo que esta solicitando lo invertirá en la compra de granos básicos

loans.use: To buy  grains  for his business.

loans.name: Esperanza

texts.es:
Mrs. C. has worked with our institution since 2007. She sells plastic products, and also earns money from selling corn-derived products out of her home, like toasted corn flour and a traditional corn and cocoa-based drink. The loans she has been given have been used as capital for her work.

Translated by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva volunteer

La señora C. trabaja con nuestra institución desde el año 2007 ella se dedica a la venta de productos plasticos y ademas cuenta con otros ingresos por venta de productos derivados del maiz los que vende en su casa, tales como tiste, pinol y otros. los prestamos que se le han otorgado ha sidi destinados a capital de trabajo.

loans.use: Purchase plastic products (e.g. bags)

loans.name: Orch

texts.en: Mrs. Orch H. is a 65-year-old food seller in Romol Village in the Kampong Cham Province, where she earns approximately $4 per day. H. has seven children, two of whom are single and five of whom are married. Her daughter, Lon Leck, contributes approximately $3 per day to the family from her earnings as a beauty salon owner, while another child sells food with H.. H. now seeks a loan of $600 to purchase more chairs and desks/tables for her business as well as to finance the plowing required to plant potatoes. In addition, she would like to use the loan proceeds to buy beauty salon supplies for Lon Leck.

loans.use: To purchase additional chairs and tables for her business and to fund the plowing of her land so that potatoes can be planted.

loans.name: Thang

texts.en: Mrs. Thang H. is a 47-year-old widow who earns approximately $5.06 per day selling sausages and groceries from her home in Koh Kor Krov Village in the Kampong Cham Province. H. has four children, one of whom is married, while the other three are single. With respect to her three single children, one is a university student, another (son) is an electrician and car repairer, and another (daughter) is an employee at the Bavet Casino. In order to strengthen her business, H. now seeks a loan of $900 to expand her inventory of groceries and sausages.

loans.use: To improve her business by increasing the inventory of groceries and sausages

loans.name: Khon

texts.en: Mr. Khon T. is a 44-year-old rice farmer and pig breeder in Kork Sandek Village in the Kampong Speu Province. He is married to Mrs. Phal Chem, who works with her husband, and they have three children, all of whom are studying at the local school. They usually work together to meet their family's needs, but Mr. Khon T. also works as a house constructor. Due to the rising price of pigs, Mr. Khon T.’s business has struggled as of late because he has been unable to buy pigs to raise. He was an AMK client previously, and he used the proceeds from the loan he received through AMK to buy a motorbike so that he could work as a taxi driver. Now, Mr. Khon T. is seeking a loan to buy pig food.

loans.use: To purchase food for the pigs he and his wife breed

loans.name: Sean

texts.en: Mrs. Sean T. is a 35-year-old rice farmer, living in Chvek Village in the Kampong Speu Province. She is the mother of three children: one child works as a construction worker, another child works at a garment factory, and the other child is enrolled in school. Her husband, Ork Dorm Run, pictured on the left, collects palm juice to sell. Mrs. Sean T. has already received one loan from AMK to buy pigs for breeding purposes, and she is a very good client as she has made all of her loan repayments on time. Because the pig-breeding business is going so well, she would like to start another business raising cows. Thus, she is seeking another loan to purchase cows.

loans.use: To embark upon a new business venture by purchasing cows.

loans.name: Kann

texts.en: Mr. Kann N. is 52 years old, and he drives a motorbike equipped with a cart to transport coal and firewood to Phnom Penh, where it is used to cook food. He lives in Kong Roth Village in the Kampong Speu Province, and he has six children. Four of his children are enrolled in a local school, while the other two children work in a garment factory. His wife, Phos Hang, pictured on the right, is a farmer, and she usually travels with her husband so that they can sell their coal and wood together. Mr. Kann N. has encountered problems with the police because they often fine him on the road. He has received one loan previously from AMK, the proceeds of which were used to buy pigs and to build a pig stall. Last year, Mr. Kann N. contracted tuberculosis, and he had to pay approximately $750 to treat the disease. However, he is now in good health, and is seeking another loan to repair his house. In addition, any excess loan proceeds would be used to buy more coal and firewood to sell in order to generate additional income for his family.

loans.use: To repair his family's house and to purchase additional coal and firewood to sell.

loans.name: Martik

texts.id:
By renting a piece of land, mother Martik lives with her husband who work as a building laborer in the self built house. All children are married and have their own family. The house is quite clean. In front of the house Mother Martik built a small Food stall, which sells local mixed ice drink, mixed rice and gado gado (indonesian peanut salad). Every morning, mother Martik made fried bananas that is offered around the house. She was a group Dinari client before, and now Mother Martik is requesting an individual loan. In the previous loan period, Mother Martik always paid her payments timely. She hopes that this current loan could add capital to her foodstall, so that she could offer more variation.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Dengan mengontrak sebidang tA., Ibu Martik tinggal berdua beserta suaminya yang berprofesi sebagai buruh bangunan disebuah rumah yang dibangunnya sendiri. Semua anaknya sudah menikah dan mempunyai keluarga sendiri. Keadaan rumahnya cukup bersih. Didepan rumahnya Ibu Martik membangun warung kecil yang menjual es campur, nasi campur dan gado-gado. Setiap pagi, Ibu martik membuat pisang goreng dan dijajakan disekitar rumahnya.Sebelumnya klien merupakan binaan DINARI dalam bentuk kelompok, dan sekarang Ibu Martik kembali mengajukan pinjaman tetapi dalm bentuk individu. Pada pinjaman periode sebelumnya Ibu Martik selalu membayar angsurannya tepat waktu. Dia berharap pinjaman kali ini bisa membantunya sebagai tambahan modal usaha bagi warungnya, sehingga jenis makanan yang dijajakan lebih bervariasi.

loans.use: To add business capital (Menambah Modal Usaha)

loans.name: Thị Liên

texts.vi:
Mrs. Tran Thi Lien is 48 years old. She grows vegetable and sells it at the market. She has 3 children, one of whom is a truck driver, while the other two are still going to school. Her husband is a construction worker, to earn some extra money for her family. Mrs. Lien wants to borrow 125USD (equivalent to 2,006,000VND) to raise pigs. Mrs. Truong Thi Toan, 51 years old, and Mrs. Nguyen Thi Thanh Xuan, 48 years old, both want to borrow 125USD each (equivalent to 2,006,000VND each) to raise pigs. Mrs. Nguyen Thi Them, 27 years old, borrows 125USD each (equivalent to 2,006,000VND) to buy piglets. Mrs. Nguyen Thi Chuyen, 43 years old, borrows 125USD each (equivalent to 2,006,000VND) to make brick and tile. Mr. Le Tuan Truong, 26 years old, wants to borrow 125USD each (equivalent to 2,006,000VND) to buy a computer to open a business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị T. Thị Liên (MS 06020006), năm nay 48 tuổi, chị trồng rau màu và đi chợ,chị có 3 con, 1 con đã đi làm lái xe còn 2 con vẫn đi học, chồng chị đi làm thợ xây để giúp gia đình có thêm thu nhập. Chị vay 2.006.000 VND để chăn nuôi lợn. Chị Trương Thị Toàn (MS: 06020007), năm nay 51 tuổi, vay 2.006.000 VND để chăn nuôi lợn. Chị Nguyễn Thị Thanh Xuân (MS: 06020008), năm nay 48 tuổi, vay 2.006.000 VND để chăn nuôi lợn. Chị Nguyễn Thị Thêm (MS: 06020009), năm nay 27 tuổi, vay 2.006.000 VND để mua lợn giống. Chị Hoàng Thị Chuyên (MS: 06020010), năm nay 43 tuổi, vay 2.006.000 VND để mua đất làm gạch, ngói. Anh Lê Tuấn Trường (MS: 06020011), năm nay 26 tuổi, vay 2.006.000 VND để mua máy tính mở của hàng kinh doanh

loans.use: Breeding animals and open a business

loans.name: Samuon

texts.en: Mrs. Samuon T. lives in Chrork Russey Village in the Kampong Speu Province, and she is both a farmer and a seller of firewood. She was born in 1983, and she is now married to Mr. Chem Chhon, pictured on the left, who works with her. Mrs. Samuon T. has three children, one of whom attends school while the others are still too young to work and study. She has already received one loan from AMK, the proceeds of which were used to buy two cows she currently uses as draft animals to plow her rice field. Last  June, her children contracted dengue fever, and it cost approximately $30 to cure those illnesses. Presently, her children have diarrhea, and she has spent $75 to send them to Phnom Penh for treatment. Because of the children's diseases (and the attendant costs in treating them), the family faces money restrictions and difficulties in their quest to finish building their house. The house is nearly completed, and merely lacks a staircase. Thus, Mrs. Samuon T. is seeking a loan to build a staircase.

loans.use: To complete the construction of their house by building a staircase.

loans.name: Vorn

texts.en: Mrs. Vorn Y. lives in Kraing Metrey Village in the Kampong Speu province. She is the mother of one child, who studies in state school. She is a subsistence farmer, cultivating her crops in a small field in the village. Her husband, Chum Ourm, pictured on the right, works with her on the rice field. With respect to their business, Mrs. Vorn Y. relies heavily on weather conditions and at times the weater conditions are extremely adverse. Since the monsoon season is fast approaching, it is more convenient and practical to grow rice at this time of the year. Unfortunately, Mrs. Vorn Y. does not have any draft animals to plow the rice field, so she is hereby seeking a loan to buy cows for this purpose.

loans.use: To purchase draft animals (cows) to plow the rice field.

loans.name: Thị Lý

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi Ly, 56 years old, want to borrow 2.006.000 VND to buy foodstuff for her breeding pigs. Pig-breeding is the main source of income for her family, with a smaller part coming from her daily reselling of groceries. One of her children is currently a carpenter and also helping out her family while her husband help her in breeding and reselling. Mrs. Nguyen Thi Danh, 49 years old, need to borrow 2.006.000 VND to buy nitrogenous fertilizer for the field. Mrs. Nguyen Thi Anh, 24 years of age and Mrs. Nguyen Thi Cam, 22 years old, both would like to borrow 560.000 each to buy fertilizers for their rice field. Mr. Nguyen Van Giang, now 61 years old, is asking for 2.006.000 VND to aid his pig-breeding and his cultivated crops.

Translated from Vietnamese by Anh Hoai Nguyen, Kiva volunteer.

Chị N. Thị Lý (MS: 06020001), năm nay 56 tuổi, chị chăn nuôi để tạo thu nhập cho gia đình, ngoài ra chị còn bán hàng khô để có thêm thu nhập hàng ngày, 1 con chị đã đi làm mộc để tạo thu nhập cho gia đình còn chồng chị ở nhà phụ giúp chi trong việc chăn nuôi và bán hàng. Chị vay 2.006.000 VND để chăn nuôi lợn và mua cám cho lợn. Chị N. Thị Dành (MS: 06020002), năm nay 49 tuổi, vay 2.006.000 VND mua phân đạm để trồng trọt. Chị N. Thị Ánh (MS: 06020003), năm nay 24 tuổi, vay 560.000 VND mua phân đạm trồng lúa. Chị N. Thị Cam (MS: 06020004), năm nay 22 tuổi, vay 560.000 VND mua phân đạm để trồng lúa. Anh N. Văn Giang (MS: 06020005), năm nay 61tuổi, vay 2.006.000 VND để chăn nuôi lợn mua phân bón cho cây trồng.

loans.use: Chăn nuôi và trồng trọt

loans.name: Rustianah

texts.id:
Ms. Rustianah has worked as a tailor for almost 7 years, and the assortments of her work consists of bags to clothings like pants and shirts. She usually accepts large contracted orders. However if the order is too large, she would share it to fellow tailor friends. With a sewing machine as capital and a motor cycle as mode of transportation, also husband's assistance, income from contracted tailoring could usually aproach Rp 1 Million (about US$ 110) including salaries. That income are usually divided with people who help her sew, also to maintain the sewing equipments.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Ibu Rustianah sudah menjadi penjahit hampir 7 tahun dan jenis jahitannya bermacam-macam mulai dari pernak-pernik seperti tas sampai pakaian seperti baju dan celana. Dia biasanya menerima pesanan dalam jumlah yang banyak (borongan). Tetapi kalau pesanannya terlalu banyak dia harus membagi dengan temannya sesama penjahit. Dengan bermodalkan mesin jahit dan sepeda motor sebagai alat transportasi dan dengan dibantu suaminya, penghasilan yang didapat dari jahit borongan seperti itu biasanya mencapai 1 juta rupiah sekali bayaran. Dari penghasilan itu biasanya dibagi dengan orang yang membantunya menjahit selain juga untuk kebutuhan perawatan peralatan menjahit.

loans.use: To add capital buy fabric (menambah Modal Membeli kain)

loans.name: Lim

texts.en: Mrs. Lim S. is 52 years old, and she lives in Champey Village in the Kampong Speu Province. She is a farmer with two children, both of whom help their parents on the rice field. Her husband, Mr. Yorn Yeim, is also a subsistence farmer. Not surprisingly, when they experience a drought, their rice production declines dramatically, thereby making it extremely difficult to maintain a decent standard of living. Moreover, in December 2007, Mrs. Lin Snguong‘s husband got tetanus, and he was sent to the local hospital. Presently, Mr. Yorn Yeim is ill again, which makes the family's budget even tighter than it was before he was sick. Facing poor living conditions and a lack of money, Mrs. Lim S. is seeking a loan to buy cows to plow the rice field to exploit the profitable rainy season.

loans.use: To purchase cows to plow the rice field to capitalize on the profitable rainy season.

loans.name: Anik

texts.id:
Anik M. lives in Wibisana street Denpasar with husband Eko Wahyudi and two children Kiki dan Dila. Ms. Anik family condition is healthy, so is the house condition. Ms. Anik and her husband is in the same business: Selling Fried chicken with raw vegetables, and usually could consume 20-25 kgs (44-55 lbs) of chicken. Ingredients for chicken vegetable are usually bought at Kumba Sari Market. Daily average Anik could profit about Rp 200,000 (about US $22). This profit is used for paying children's education, and also daily household expenses. Anik M. very much hopes that this loan could be used to add business capital.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Anik M. tingal di Jl.Wibisana Denpasar bersama suaminya Eko Wahyudi dan kedua orang anaknya Kiki dan Dila. Kondisi keluarga Ibu Anik sehat, begitu juga dengan keadaan rumahnya. Pekerjaan Ibu Anik dan suaminya sama yaitu menjual Ayam Goreng lalapan, dan biasanya setiap hari bisa menghabiskan 20 – 25 kg ayam. Bahan untuk lalapan ayam biasanya dibeli di Pasar Kumba Sari. Rata-tata perhari Anik bisa menghasilkan keuntungan sekitar Rp. 200.000.-. Keuntungan yang didapatkan digunakan sebagai biaya pendidikan sekolah anaknya dan juga untuk keperluan rumah tangga sehari-hari. Anik M. sangat berharap pinjaman kali ini bisa dijadikan sebagai tambahan modal usaha.

loans.use: Business capital (Modal Usaha)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase a tent and chairs

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Mr. Kim S. is 30 years old, and he earns approximately $6 per day selling used goods. His wife, Chin Somphos, is a 23-year-old vegetable seller at the Boung Kok Market, where she is able to earn approximately $1.50 per day. They live in Thmor Korl Village in the Kampong Cham Province with their two children, one of whom is student, while the other child is only 4 years old. In order to help his wife support their family, S. seeks a loan in the amount of $800 to enlarge his used goods-selling business.

loans.use: To expand his business of selling used goods

loans.name: Zebo

texts.ru:
Zebo K., 47, lives in Rudaki district. She is married and has four children. Zebo sells food products for a living. She has a trading stall at the "Safari" market in Dushanbe. Her husband is working in Russia at the moment, so Zebo must take full responsibility for her family. She has a good spot at the market and her business is well organized. The only lack is in her assortment of goods. Zebo is applying for a loan in order to increase her sales volume. She can repay the loan within ten months.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva volunteer.

Косимова Зебо проживает в районе Рудаки. Ей 47 лет. Она замужем и имеет 4 детей. Занимается торговлей продуктов питания. Имеет торговую точку на рынке «Сафари» города Душанбе.Муж ее уехал в Россию на заработки , поэтому ответственность за ее семью лежит полностью на Зебо. У нее хорошее место и бизнес налажен. Только не хватает ассортимента товара. Поэтому она планирует получить кредит, чтобы увеличить товарооборот. А погасить кредит сможет в течении 10 месяцев.

loans.use: To increase sales volume

loans.name: Abdul Samat

texts.en: Abdul Samat lives in district 11 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is uneducated. He is a butcher, a business he started five years ago with the help of his father. Now he wants to expand his business so he wants to take out an individual loan to enlarge his shop and expand his stock to make a good income and support his family. He is happy that he can further his business. He would like to thank those who help poor people around this country.

loans.use: To expand his shop

loans.name: Saida

texts.ru:
Saida M. lives in Rudaki district, in the village of Gizhdaloobod. She works as a teacher in a secondary school. Saida has a large and happy family- five children and two grandchildren. She has experience raising animals, and she would like to buy a few sheep. This will help her family get some additional income. Besides this, she is a very active woman and has a lot of free time. To achieve her goal, Saida is applying for a loan of 450 US dollars. She can repay her loan within nine months.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva volunteer.

Махминова Саида проживает в районе Рудаки в поселке Гиждалообод. Работает учителем в средней школе. Имеет большую и дружную семью. У нее 5 детей и 2 внуков. Имеет опыт работы в животноводстве. Поэтому хочет закупить нескольких овец. Это поможет ее семье получать дополнительный доход. Кроме того она очень активная женщина и у нее много свободного времени.Для достижения этой цели Саида хочет получить кредит в размере 450 долларов США, а погасить кредит она сможет в течении 9 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase sheep

loans.name: Tojinisso

texts.ru:
Tojinisso J. lives in Rudaki district. She is 53. She has a large family: a husband and four children. Tojinisso works as an elementary school teacher in Rudaki district. At home she also has a small livestock business raising animals. She has been doing this for about 20 years. This winter, the nation's poor economic conditions also rubbed off on Tojinisso's business and several of her sheep died. Tojinisso would like to rebuild her business. To do this, she needs a loan of 450 US dollars to buy more sheep. She can repay her loan within eight months.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva volunteer.

Джобирова Тоджиниссо проживает в районе Рудаки . Ей 53 года. У нее большая семья:муж и четверо детей. Работает учителем начальных классов в средней школе , района Рудаки. У себя дома имеет небольшое хозяйство, где разводит мелко-рогатый скот. Занимается этим бизнесом уже около 20 лет.Зимой неблагоприятные условия отразились на ее хозяйстве. Несколько из ее овец померзли. Поэтому Тоджиниссо хочет восстановить свое дело. Для этого ей нужно получить кредит в размере 450 долларов США и закупить нескольких овец. А погасить кредит сможет в течении 8 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase sheep

loans.name: Sudiartinik

texts.id: Sudiartinik (53 tahun) tinggal di Jl. Resimuka Barat bersama suaminya Badur yang berprofesi sebagai Tukang Listrik keliling. Kedua anaknya Sandy dan Yulianto sudah mandiri, dan keadaan keluarganya sehat, begitu juga dengan keadaan rumahnya bersih. Kegiatan Sudiartinik sehari-hari adalah sebagai penjual rujak dan sate ayam dan biasanya dia belanja bahan-bahan jualannya di Pasar Saera. Khusus untuk sate ayam, biasanya Sudiartinik menghabiskan 3-4 kg usus ayam sedangkan untuk rujaknya biasanya tidak tentu, tergantung banyaknya pembeli. Pendapatan dalam sehari bisa mencapai Rp. 50.000 dan itu cukup untuk kebutuhan sehari-hari. Sudiartinik sangant mengharapkan bantuan modal sehingga usahanya semakin berkembang.

loans.use: Menambah Modal Usaha

loans.name: Sudiartinik

texts.id:
Sudiartinik (53 tyears) lives in Resimuka Barat street with her husband Badur an independent electrician. Both children Sandy and Yulianto are independent. The family is healthy, and the house clean. Sudiartinik daily activities as rujak (indonesian type salad), and chicken satay (chicken on sticks barbecued) includes normally buying the ingredients at Saera market. Specially for chicken satay, Sudiartinik bought 6-8 lbs of chicken intestine, while for rujak usually not fixed, depending on how many buyers. Daily income could reach Rp 50,000 (about US$ 6), and that is enough for daily needs. Sudiartinik very much hope for additional capital so that her business could grow.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Sudiartinik (53 tahun) tinggal di Jl. Resimuka Barat bersama suaminya Badur yang berprofesi sebagai Tukang Listrik keliling. Kedua anaknya Sandy dan Yulianto sudah mandiri, dan keadaan keluarganya sehat, begitu juga dengan keadaan rumahnya bersih. Kegiatan Sudiartinik sehari-hari adalah sebagai penjual rujak dan sate ayam dan biasanya dia belanja bahan-bahan jualannya di Pasar Saera. Khusus untuk sate ayam, biasanya Sudiartinik menghabiskan 3-4 kg usus ayam sedangkan untuk rujaknya biasanya tidak tentu, tergantung banyaknya pembeli. Pendapatan dalam sehari bisa mencapai Rp. 50.000 dan itu cukup untuk kebutuhan sehari-hari. Sudiartinik sangant mengharapkan bantuan modal sehingga usahanya semakin berkembang.

loans.use: To add business capital (Menambah Modal Usaha)

loans.name: Tem

texts.en: Mrs. Tem C. is 50 years old, and she earns approximately $1.66 per day working as a grocer from her home. Her husband, Et Vy, also earns approximately $1.66 per day selling groceries with her. They live with their four children in Ann Doung Chea Village in the Kampong Cham Province. One of their two single children is a worker in Thailand, while their other single child is a student. C. is seeking a loan of $500 to expand her grocery-selling business as well as to purchase more small pigs to raise. With the additional income she expects to generate from her business by virtue of this loan, she will be able to cover her family’s expenses and to send her children to school.

loans.use: To expand her grocery-selling business and to purchase additional pigs to raise

loans.name: Niaz Din

texts.en: Niaz Din lives in district 7 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is single. His father died 3 years ago during the war, so he is supporting his family. He has a shop where he sells construction supplies. He needs to complete his stock so he wants to take out an individual loan to complete materials lacking in his inventory so as to make a good monthly income to help his family and make a better future for himself.

loans.use: To complete materials lacking in his inventory

loans.name: Kasdu

texts.id:
The loan this time would be the second loan for Kasdu. The previous loan is paid off, and payments were timely. Mr. Kasdu profession is snack sales, which sells well, and up to now expanding, only Mr. Kasdu is constricted by capital. The plan for this loan is to be the capital to add additional assortment of snacks in his shop, and he hopes the received profit from Rp 60,000 could be increased to Rp 70,000 (Translators note: 1US$ fluctuates between Rp 8,000 to Rp 10,000). At this time Mr. Kasdu still lives in Silayuk street, Kerobokan village, with wife and child. The family is healthy.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Pinjaman kali ini merupakn pinjaman yang kedua bagi Kasdu. Pinjaman pada periode sebelumnya telah lunas, dan pembayarannya pun lancar. Profesi Pak Kasu adalah penjual makanan ringan. Berbagai macam makanan ringan yang dijualnya sangat laris dan sampai saat ini mengalami perkembangan, hanya saja Pak Kasdu terkendala dengan modal usaha. Rencananya pinjaman kali ini akan dijadikan modal usaha untuk menambah berbagai macam makanan ringan ditokonya dan diharapkan keuntungan yang didapat Rp.60.000 dapat meningkat menjadi Rp.70.000.-Saat ini Pak Kasdu masih tinggal di Jl. Silayuki Kerobokan bersama istri dan anaknya. Keadaan keluarganya sehat.

loans.use: To add business capital (Menambah Modal Usaha)

loans.name: Sayaad Mohammad

texts.en: Sayaad Mohammad lives in district 12 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and is the father of one son. He has a small carpet weaving business. He has 6 students who are very hard workers. He exports Afghani carpets to different countries. He wants to expand his business so he has requested an individual loan to buy one or two new machines to continue his business with more success. He is happy.

loans.use: To buy one or two new machines

loans.name: Parween

texts.en: Parween lives in district 11 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is a widow and has five children who are in school. She is the one to support her family. She is a tailor and has good experience and a good number of clients. She works in her home. She wants to expand her business so she has requested an individual loan to buy new machines and open a tailoring shop to make good income and help her children to make a better future for her family. She is happy.

loans.use: To buy new machines

loans.name: Fatuma's Mshikamano Group

texts.en:
Fatuma is 38 years old and is married with 1 child, age 5. Fatuma owns a small beauty salon, which she started in 2005. Every day she works from 8:00 AM to 8:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $180 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items (weaving, hair treatment) for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Asha, who has a business dealing in veterinary sales.

loans.use: To buy more items (weaving, hair treatment) for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Kung

texts.en: Kung C. is 44 years old, unmarried, and working as both a farmer and an electrician in Siem Reap Province. He makes $6 U.S. per day in his business. Kung wants to make his farm more efficient by purchasing a water pump that will be used to better irrigate his fields, thus his request for a $300 loan..

loans.use: To purchase a water pump.

loans.name: Abed

texts.en: Abed is 58 years old and has one child. He lives with his family in southern Lebanon, in the town of Saida. Abed is a taxi driver, and also sells clothing. He has applied for his first loan from A. Majmoua, which he would like to use to buy new items to sell from his retail business.

loans.use: to buy merchandise

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Saleh

texts.en: Saleh is a 33 years old and has four children. He lives with his family in the southern Lebanese town of Saida. Saleh makes a living selling scrap, and also owns a grocery store. He has applied for his third loan from Al Majmoua. He plans to use this latest loan to close down his current grocery store and open up a new one.

loans.use: to open up a new grocery store

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is 29 years old and has one child. He lives with his family in southern Lebanon, in the town of Saida. Ahmad makes a living by running a grocery store. He has applied for his first loan from Al Majmoua, and he would like to use the funds to buy additional merchandise to sell to his customers.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell in his grocery store

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Faten

texts.en: Faten is 41 years old and has three children. She lives with her family in southern Lebanon, in the town of Saida, where she runs a grocery store. Faten has applied for her third loan from A. Majmoua. She plans to use the money to buy additionA. merchandise to sell to her customers.

loans.use: to buy groceries to sell in her store

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en: Fatima is 42 years old and has four children. She lives with her family in southern Lebanon, in the town of Saida. Fatima runs a small shop, and is applying for her fourth loan from Al Majmoua. She plans to use this loan to buy merchandise that she can sell to her customers. The increased income made possible by the loan will allow her to pay her son's university tuition.

loans.use: to buy merchandise to sell in her store

loans.name: Abed Al Salam

texts.en: Abed Al Salam is 43 years old and has six children. He lives with his family in southern Lebanon, in the town of Saida, where he makes a living as a carpenter. He is applying for his sixth loan from Al Majmoua. He plans to use this latest loan to buy wood to use in his business.

loans.use: to buy wood for a carpentry business

loans.name: Samer

texts.en: Samer is 39 years old and has three children. He lives with his family in southern Lebanon, in the town of Saida. Samer repairs and paints cars for a living. He has applied for his third loan from Al Majmoua. He plans to use this loan to buy a damaged car, repair it and then sell it.

loans.use: to buy a car he can repair and sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: B.

texts.id:
S., apart from as seller of second-hand things, she is also professional of beads tailor, she could make sandals, clothes or anything that could be created from the beads decoration.

She usually takes beads from Garment around his localities then afterwards she is sewing and circulated the item to buyers around her. She took the profit from the cost of sewing and also from circulation.

For sandals, usually S. is paid Rp.2.500 per the pair, whereas the selling cost is usually Rp.500 per the pair.

She is using the motorcycle and the cart to circulating the item. S. really expected help to increase capital of her efforts to buy second-hand things and to increase her capital

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Carlos Patriawan, Kiva Volunteer.

S., selain sebagai seorang pengumpul barang-barang bekas, ia juga berprofesi sebagai penjahit mote, bisa berupa sandal, baju atau apa saja yang bisa diberi hiasan mote. Ia biasanya mengambil mote dari Garment disekitarnya lalu kemudian dijahit dan diedarkan ke pembeli-pembeli disekelilingnya. Keuntungan yang didapat bisa dari ongkos jahit dan juga dari ongkos mengedarkan. Khusus untuk sandal, biasanya S. dibayar Rp.2.500 per pasang, sedangkan ongkos mengedarkan biasanya Rp.500 per pasang. Sehari-harinya sepeda motor dan gerobak adalah sarana yang digunakan oleh S.. S. sangat mengharapkan bantuan untuk menambah modal usaha membeli barang-barang bekas dan untuk menambah modal menjahit sandal mote.

loans.use: Increasing working capital

loans.name: B.

texts.id: S., selain sebagai seorang pengumpul barang-barang bekas, ia juga berprofesi sebagai penjahit mote, bisa berupa sandal, baju atau apa saja yang bisa diberi hiasan mote. Ia biasanya mengambil mote dari Garment disekitarnya lalu kemudian dijahit dan diedarkan ke pembeli-pembeli disekelilingnya. Keuntungan yang didapat bisa dari ongkos jahit dan juga dari ongkos mengedarkan. Khusus untuk sandal, biasanya S. dibayar Rp.2.500 per pasang, sedangkan ongkos mengedarkan biasanya Rp.500 per pasang. Sehari-harinya sepeda motor dan gerobak adalah sarana yang digunakan oleh S.. S. sangat mengharapkan bantuan untuk menambah modal usaha membeli barang-barang bekas dan untuk menambah modal menjahit sandal mote.

loans.use: Untuk Menambah Modal Usaha

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is 33 years old and has two children. He works and lives with his family in the town of Saida in southern Lebanon. Ali makes a living by selling chickens and sandwiches. This is his second loan from A. Majmoua, and he plans to use it to buy a generator for his business.

loans.use: to buy a generator

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Youssef

texts.en: Youssef is 63 years old and works and lives in southern Lebanon, in the town of Saida. Youssef is a farmer, and has applied for his second loan from A. Majmoua. He will use the loan to buy the supplies he needs to maintain and improve his farm.

loans.use: to buy supplies for his farm

loans.name: B.

texts.id:
Besides being a used junk collector, S. also works as an embroiderer. She works on sandals, clothes or any garments that can be embroidered. She usually buys pieces to be embroidered from nearby garment factories which was then worked on and resold to buyers in the neighborhood. THe profit comes from labor fee and distribution fee. For Sandals, S. can get 25 cents per pair while the distribution fee is about 5 cents. She uses her motorcycle or pulled cart to distribute her goods. S. hopes the loan will help her increase her business volume. p> Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

S., selain sebagai seorang pengumpul barang-barang bekas, ia juga berprofesi sebagai penjahit mote, bisa berupa sandal, baju atau apa saja yang bisa diberi hiasan mote. Ia biasanya mengambil mote dari Garment disekitarnya lalu kemudian dijahit dan diedarkan ke pembeli-pembeli disekelilingnya. Keuntungan yang didapat bisa dari ongkos jahit dan juga dari ongkos mengedarkan. Khusus untuk sandal, biasanya S. dibayar Rp.2.500 per pasang, sedangkan ongkos mengedarkan biasanya Rp.500 per pasang. Sehari-harinya sepeda motor dan gerobak adalah sarana yang digunakan oleh S.. S. sangat mengharapkan bantuan untuk menambah modal usaha membeli barang-barang bekas dan untuk menambah modal menjahit sandal mote.

loans.use: Increase business capital

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is 20 years old and is single with 1 child, age 4. Aisha owns a small food vending store, which she started in 2006. Every day she works from 8:00 AM to 6:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Sary

texts.en: Mrs. Sary C. is 43 years old, and she lives in Kraing Metrey Village in the province of Kampong Speu. She is a farmer and the mother of eight children, five of whom study in the local school, two of whom work, and the last of whom stays at home. Her husband, Thy Kan, pictured on the left, works with her on the rice field. Despite the fact that the family is disease-free, the family nonetheless lives in very poor conditions. Further, Mrs. Sary C. has incurred significant expenses in recent years on account of wedding ceremonies, funerals, and other similar such expenses. As for her work in cultivating rice, she relies heavily on good weather conditions and she uses old equipment; in fact, she does not even have a draft animal to plow the rice field. Therefore, she is seeking a loan to be able to afford cows for this purpose.

loans.use: To purchase cows to plow the rice field.

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is 22 years old and is married with 3 children, ages 8, 6, and 3. Mwanakombo is a cloth seller; she started her business in 2003. Every day she works from 8:00 AM to 7:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more cloth for her business.

loans.use: To buy more cloth for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Mwanahawa's Majengo D Group

texts.en:
Mwanahawa is 30 years old and is married with 2 children, ages 10 and 3. Mwanahawa owns a small grocery, which she started in 2006. Every day she works from 7:00 AM to 10:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items (alcohol and soft drinks) for her grocery. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Mariam and Rahma, who have businesses dealing in tailoring and grocery and fish sales.

loans.use: To buy more items (alcohol and soft drinks) for her grocery

loans.name: Asriyani

texts.id:
Mrs. Asriyani A. is 30 year old. She has 2 little children. Asriyani owns a business selling clothes around her neighborhood. She uses part of the profit to increase her business capital, and she uses the rest to fulfill her family's daily needs. Asriani buys clothes from her friend then resold around the neighborhood door to door using a motorcycle. The loan will be used to increase her business capital to buy more clothes to be resold. Few years ago Asriyani was DINARI's group client but now she is applying to be an individual client.

b> Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Ibu Asriyani A. adalah seorang ibu rumah tangga yang berusia 30 tahun. Dia memiliki 2 orang anak yang masih kecil. Kesehariannya Asriayani memiliki usaha sebagai penjual baju keliling dimana keuntungan dari usahanya itu sebagian dia pakai untuk menambahkan modal usaha yang sudah ada dan sebagian lagi dia pakai untuk memenuhi kebutuhan rumah tangga dan keluarga. Dalam menjalankan usahanya Asriyani mengambil baju dari temannya kemudian dijual keliling dari rumah ke rumah menggunakan sepeda motor. Dari pinjaman kA. ini, Asriyani sangat berharap bisa dijadikan tambahan modal usaha untuk membeli baju yang lalu kemudian dijual lagi. Beberapa tahun yang lalu Asriyani pernah menjadi klien DINARI dalam bentuk kelompok, tetapi kA. ini dia menjadi klien individu.

loans.use: Increase business capital

loans.name: Albertina

texts.en:
Albertina is 47 years old and originally from the capital city Maputo. She is a widow as her husband passed away after more than 15 years of marriage. She has 6 children and 3 grandchildren, but only the 3 youngest children (ranging from 14 to 8 years old) and the 3 grandchildren live with her. They all attend school, apart from the youngest grandchild who is only 3 years old.

Albertina moved with her family to Namaacha, a village bordering Swaziland, when she was little. She went to school until third grade, but stopped due to her family’s difficult financial situation. She got pregnant with her first son at 17 years old and has been living with her future husband ever since, taking care of the house and the children.

Soon after Albertina’s husband passed away in 2001, Albertina started to sell clothes in Namaacha. She has a stand at the local open market that is open twice a week (Wednesdays and Saturdays). During the other days of the week, Albertina sells from her house. The most sold items are sheets; each is sold for Mozambique Metical (MZN)15 or 30, depending on the quality and design. Albertina goes to Maputo to buy merchandise once a month, paying around MZN60 in transportation costs. At the market, Albertina makes between MZN300 and 1,500 per day, really depending on the season and weather conditions.

Albertina first heard of Hluvuku through a friend who was a client. This will be Albertina’s second loan. The first loan was used to buy inventory and helped increase sales. Albertina was extremely happy with the loan, as it helped her buy basic needs for her children and also increase her monthly profits. This time Albertina intends to use the loan to buy winter clothes, as winter will soon start and she thinks she will be able to sell a lot.

In the future, Albertina would like to ask for a new loan to help her finish building a shop in front of her house, where she would be able to sell not only clothes, but also food and basic needs products. The picture shows Albertina with the sheets at her house.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary is 25 years old and is single with 1 child, age 10. Rosemary is a soap seller; she started her business in 2001. Every day she works from 7:30 AM to 4:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more soap for her business.

loans.use: To buy more soap for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Lurdes Celeste

texts.en:
Lurdes is 40 years old and originally from the capital city Maputo. She has been married for 22 years and has 3 children: a 22 year old woman who is attending the teacher’s professional school, a 19 year old woman who is attending the labor professional school, and a 14 year old boy who is still in 9th grade at the secondary school.

Lurdes studied until 6th grade in Maputo, but in 1984 had to move to Namaacha to take care of her uncle’s children, as he was moving to Inhambane Province to work. The schools in Namaacha were full, so Lurdes couldn’t attend 7th grade that year. The following year Lurdes met her husband and got married, never going back to school again.

Lurdes and her family live at her own house. She has a small grocery shop in front of her house where she sells mainly food and basic needs products. She sells some soft drinks, but refuses to sell alcohol. Her daily income is very related to her inventory. When she has a lot of products to offer she can make up to Mozambique Metical (MZN) 700 in a day. The most sold product is soap: a “Bingo” package of 500mg costs MZN10.

This will be Lurdes’ first ever loan. Chitchatting with her friends she mentioned she was considering asking for some money from lenders at the border (Namaacha borders Swaziland), who charge 100% interest rate, in order to buy inventory. One of the friends, who is an Hluvuku client, told her about the institution and she is very happy about it. This loan will be used to buy inventory and increase sales.

In the future, Lurdes would like to improve her grocery shop and eventually open a new shop at the local market, where she would be able to sell more products.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Moshi's Majengo North Group

texts.en:
Moshi is 38 years old and is married with 5 children. Moshi owns a small food vending store, which she started in 2000. Every day she works from 6:30 AM to 8:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $120 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Batuli and Rehema, who have businesses dealing in a grocery and charcoal sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Asha's Majengo North Group

texts.en:
Asha is 26 years old and is married with 1 child, age 2. Asha is a cloth seller; she started her business in 2007. Every day she works from 8:00 AM to 3:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $65 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more cloth for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Rehema, who has a business dealing in cloth sales.

loans.use: To buy more cloth for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Francisco

texts.en:
Francisco is 66 years old and originally from Inhambane Province. He has been married since 1979 and had 11 children, but unfortunately just 8 are still alive. Today he supports 7 children and 2 grandchildren; most of them are still attending school, but the oldest is already working to help with his siblings’ school fees.

Francisco finished primary school in Inhambane and in 1972 moved to Maputo to work for a mining company. In 1992, he moved to Namaacha to work as a construction worker and never left the village again. Francisco currently works at Namaacha’s open market. He owns 3 stands. He is currently renting two because he has no money to buy inventory and at the third he sells shoes. Francisco buys the shoes at the border country Swaziland for Mozambique Metical (MZN) 250 per pair, and sells for MZN275 or 300 (depending on the design). On top of that, Francisco also sews clients’ clothes, making some additional money. As the market is only open on Wednesdays and Saturdays, Francisco is barely able to cover household expenses.

Francisco is also a pastor at the Isione Church. He celebrates mass every Sunday at 10:30 am, but misses the time that he was able to have mass every night. According to Francisco, after civil war started no one attended church at night again, not even when the war was over.

This will be Francisco’s second loan with Hluvuku. The first was used to buy inventory, and helped Francisco increase his monthly income. This loan will still be used to buy more products. Francisco is hopeful that he will again increase his income a little bit more.

In the future, Francisco would like to build a stand at his house to sell shoes every day of the week.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is 28 years old and is married woman with 1 child age 9 months. Maria is a tailoring and she is a cloth seller, she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more tailoring items and cloth items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring items and cloth items for her business.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is 28 years old and is married with 1 child, age 9 months. Maria is a tailor, and she is a cloth seller; she started her business in 2007. Every day she works from 8:00 AM to 6:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more tailoring items and cloth items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring items and cloth items for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Celina Armando

texts.en:
Celina is a beautiful, lively, and hard-working 27-year-old woman, originally from the capital city Maputo. She finished primary school in Maputo and didn’t attend secondary school because she got married.

Celina comes from a wealthier family than her husband; her father is a good carpenter in Maputo and always gave comfort to his family. Celina faced a lot of prejudice from her family when she decided to get married to a man who had no financial conditions at all, but she knew he was the right one. They have been married for 13 years now and today Celina’s family loves him. They have 3 children: a 10-year-old girl, a 7-year-old boy and a 4-year-old boy. The 2 oldest attend primary school and the youngest go to kindergarten.

Celina and her husband moved to Ponta D’Ouro, a village bordering South Africa very famous for tourism, for 2 years, but moved back to Maputo when she found a better job. In 2001 her husband found a job in a hotel in Namaacha, a village bordering Swaziland, so she moved there as well and started to work at the same hotel in the laundry department. In 2005 her husband was fired and moved back to Ponta D’Ouro to work at a hotel there, but Celina decided to stay in Namaacha as her work was doing very well. She earns a minimum wage salary per month, in 2001 it was Mozambique Metical (MZN)850 and today it is MZN1,600. She works either between 6:00 am to 2:00 pm, or between 2:00 pm to 10:00 pm, and she has a cousin who stays home with the kids. The cousin is 19 years old and attends secondary school in the morning as well. On top of that income, Celina’s husband sends her MZN3,000 monthly, helping with the household expenses and with their project of building a house.

This will be Celina’s first loan. She heard about Hluvuku through a friend who is a client and decided to ask for a loan to buy more construction material and speed up the construction. With this loan, Celina will be able to finish the 2 rooms (including roofing), will move there and stop paying the current MZN500 per month in rent. It will still be necessary to finish the living room and kitchen, but Celina is extremely positive that she will be able to do it in 2 more loans.

In the future, Celina would like to build a small grocery shop or a bakery near her house to have a business to leave for her children. She dreams of giving her children the same luxury she had when she was a kid, and with her strength she will definitely succeed.

loans.use: Buy construction materials

loans.name: Hekmat

texts.en: Hekmat is 56 years old and the father of six children. He works and lives with his family in southern Lebanon, in the town of Saida. Hekmat supports his family by running a nursery, where he grows roses. He has applied for his second loan from A. Majmoua, which he will use to expand his business by finishing work on four greenhouses .

loans.use: to complete work on four greenhouses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Rabih

loans.use: to buy supplies for a car-repair business

loans.name: Mustafa

texts.en: Mustafa is 62 years old and lives and works in the town of Saida in southern Lebanon. He makes a living selling a variety of items, including fruits, vegetables and carpets. He is applying for a loan to buy more merchandise to sell to his customers.

loans.use: to buy various types of merchandise to sell to his customers

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is 21 years old and is single with 2 children, ages 5 and 1. Mariam is a firewood seller; she started her business in 2007. Every day she works from 7:00 AM to 3:30 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more firewood for her business.

loans.use: To buy more firewood for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Ziad

texts.en: Ziad is 34 years old and lives and works in the southern Lebanese town of Saida. He makes a living selling groceries and vegetables. Ziad has applied for his third loan from A. Majmoua, which he will use to buy new merchandise to sell to his customers.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for a grocery store

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta is 40 years old and originally from Namaacha. She was married for many years, but her husband left her a couple of years ago and moved to South Africa. Julieta has 6 children ranging from 25 to 6 years old. All attend school, expect from the older one who is already working to help with the household expenses.

Julieta just studied until 2nd grade, as she had to work to help her family’s difficult financial situation. Soon after Julieta had her first son and got married, she started to sell baskets bought in the capital city Maputo in Namaacha, where she would buy shoes and go back to Maputo to sell them. Ten years ago, Julieta started to sell only pots and pans made in Maputo. The person that produces those pots comes from Maputo to sell to her and Julieta then sells them at Namaacha’s open market. Julieta buys each pot for Mozambique Metical (MZN) 120 to MZN230 and sells them for MZN180-270. Julieta makes between MZN1,000-3,000 per day, but unfortunately the market is only open twice a week (on Wednesdays and Saturdays).

This will be Julieta’s first loan. She heard about Hluvuku during a conversation with a friend, and decided to apply as well. This loan will be used to increase her inventory and help increase sales. According to Julieta, the more products there are in the stand, the more the stand sells.

In the future, Julieta would like to ask for a new loan to build a stand at her house where she would be able to sell her products during every day of the week.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is 30 years old and works and lives in the southern Lebanese town of Saida. He makes a living as a printer, and has applied for his second loan from A. Majmoua. He will use the loan to buy new equipment for his shop.

loans.use: to  buy new equipment for a printing business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

Salim has applied for his third loan from Al Majmoua, which he will use to buy the materials he needs to run his business. He will use the increased income made possible by the loan to pay his children's tuition fees.

loans.use: to buy materials for a carpentry business

loans.name: Fatuma's Mandingo Group

texts.en:
Fatuma is 27 years old and is married with 4 children, ages 6 to 11. Fatuma owns a small grocery store, which she started in 2001. Every day she works from 6:15 AM to 9:30 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more grocery items (alcohol and soft drinks) for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Fatuma, Pili, and Sera, who have businesses dealing in food vending and cloth and shoes sales.

loans.name: Khodr

texts.en: Khodr is 33 years old and works and lives in southern Lebanon, in the town of Saida. Khodr supports himself by making items out of aluminium. He has applied for his first loan from Al Majmoua, which he will use to buy materials for his business. He will use the increased income made possible by the loan to pay for the cost of getting engaged to his future wife.

loans.use: to buy materials for an aluminium business

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel is a forty-year-old married father of three children. His wife is a seamstress. Samuel has been selling auto parts of different kinds for over twenty years. He rents a space from which he sells various shock absorbers and fenders. The proceeds of his loan will allow him to purchase more products from overseas (Europe, Korea). In Ghana, there are no auto parts stores but there is a high demand for parts as the taxi networks are the main transportation option. He sells his wares in an area of Accra called Abossey-Okai that is a conglomeration of hundreds of entrepreneurs who each sell specific auto parts. Samuel is a member of the lending group Not Yours. The lending group works as a type of social collateral where each member of the group applies pressure on other members to ensure repayment.

loans.use: Samuel would like to import more shock absorbers.

loans.name: Nasser

texts.en: Nasser is 37 years old and works and lives with his family in the town of Saida in southern Lebanon. Nasser supports his family by making items out of aluminum, and has applied for his third loan from A. Majmoua. He will use the loan to buy raw materials, and use the increased income he expects to earn to pay his children's tuition and furnish his house.

loans.use: to buy materials for an aluminium business

loans.name: Mustafa

texts.en: Mustafa is 35 years old and the father of one child. He works and lives with his family in the town of Saida in southern Lebanon. Mustafa makes a living repairing, painting and selling cars. He has applied for his sixth loan from Al Majmoua, which he will use to buy cars to work on and then resell.

loans.use: to buy cars to repair and then resell

loans.name: Yaw

texts.en:
Yaw is a thirty-nine year old married father of three children. His wife is a hairdresser. Yaw has been selling auto parts of different kinds for over fifteen years. Currently, he sells shock absorbers, lower arms and doors. The proceeds of this loan will allow him to purchase more products from overseas (Germany, Korea, and Japan). In Ghana, there are no auto parts stores but there is a high demand for parts as the taxi networks are the main transportation option. He sells his wares in an area of Accra called Abossey-Okai that is a conglomeration of hundreds of entrepreneurs who each sell specific auto parts.

He hopes the loan proceeds will help him increase his sales volume so that he can continue to save for his children’s education.

Yaw is a member of the lending group Not Yours. The lending group works as a type of social collateral where each member of the group applies pressure on other members to ensure repayment.

loans.use: Yaw would like to import more shock absorbers .

loans.name: Akwasi

texts.en:
Akwasi is a thirty-nine year old married father of two children. His wife buys clothes in Togo and sells them in Ghana. Akwasi has been selling auto parts of different kinds for over fifteen years. Currently, he sells shock absorbers, front brakes, and lower arms. The proceeds of this loan will allow him to purchase more products from overseas (US and Japan). In Ghana, there are no auto parts stores but there is a high demand for parts as the taxi networks are the main transportation option. He sells his wares in an area of Accra called Abossey-Okai that is a conglomeration of hundreds of entrepreneurs who each sell specific auto parts.

Akwasi is a member of the lending group Not Yours. The lending group works as a type of social collateral where each member of the group applies pressure on other members to ensure repayment.

loans.use: Akwasi would like to import more shock absorbers to sell.

loans.name: Aydin

He lives with his wife and three children in a small village in the Imishli region. He has applied for a loan to expand his business and purchase two dairy cows. He believes this loan and the new cows will help him to improve the conditions of his family.

loans.use: To purchase two dairy cows

loans.name: Aga

texts.en: Aga A. is a 65 year old businessman who owns his small café in the Imishli region. He began his business in 1993 when he first rented a small place and opened his first café there. He has now purchased land and has built his own café, where he works from early morning until late night. He is married and has 5 children, and sometimes his children help him. His café is the only source of income for Aga`s family and Aga tries very hard to keep it up, but he needs additional  funds to repair and improve the condition of his working place. For this purpose, he has applied for a loan.

loans.use: To improve the condition of his café

Nixon is a member of the lending group Not Yours. The lending group works as a type of social collateral where each member of the group applies pressure on other members to ensure repayment.

Now Azad would like to expand the number of products he sells and improve the conditions of his store. Azad is married and has 2 small children. He tries very hard to take care of his family, but it is very hard for him. Azad decided to apply for a loan to purchase more products, which will help him to attract more clients and earn more money.

loans.name: Silas

texts.en:
Silas is a twenty-eight-year old, married owner of an auto parts shop. Silas has been selling auto parts of different kinds for over four years. Currently, he sells mostly beams.

In Ghana, there are no auto parts stores, but there is a high demand for parts, because the taxi networks are the main transportation option. Silas sells his wares in an area of Accra called Abossey-Okai that is a conglomeration of hundreds of entrepreneurs, each of whom sells a specific auto part.

The proceeds of his loan will allow Silas to purchase more products from overseas (Japan).

Silas is a member of the "Not Yours" lending group. The lending group works with a type of social collateral where each member of the group applies pressure on other members to ensure repayment.

loans.use: To import more auto beams.

loans.use: To purchase dairy cows

loans.name: Bayram

As mutton is very popular among Azerbaijani people, Bayram believes this business will one day provide him with a good income. He is married and has three children. He tries very hard and spends most of his day looking for his herd. Now he has applied for a loan which he will use to purchase 20 sheep for an estimated cost of USD60 each.

loans.use: To purchase 20 sheep

loans.name: Cynthia

Cynthia is thirty years old and she has been selling groceries, such as rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, skimmed powdered milk, cocoa products, assorted biscuits, candies, and canned soft drinks in Cape Coast for the past four years. Cynthia wants to use her loan to buy more products.

She is a member of the group called "Our Helper." Members of the group use peer pressure as social collateral to repay the loan.

The photo shows Cynthia with Lawrence, the loan officer.

loans.use: To buy more food for her grocery store.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is twenty-five years old and an unmarried young woman. She has been selling grocery products, such as spices, vegetable oils, palm oils, pastas, peanuts batter, and rice, for the past six years.

She wants to use her loan to buy more groceries. She wants to use proceed from her operation to expand the store, because it is currently small.

Ruth is a member of the "Our Helper" group. Members agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for her store

loans.name: Maame

texts.en:

She wants to use proceeds of her operation to expand her store. She wants to use her loan to buy more products.

E. is member of the group called "Our Helper." Members agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more garden eggs, tomatoes, ginger, onions, etc

They have one child and he is a student. This is her first loan and Sadeta will use it for buying new printer and other computer equipment. She wants to improve working conditions for her son and herself so that she can translate, write and print seminar and diploma papers in a better way. Sadeta provides additional money for her family by doing this work.

loans.use: For buying new printer

He will use the proceeds of the loan to expand his business and purchase more traditional medicines. He currently has one employee.

Kennedy is a member of the "David" lending group. The lending group works with a type of social collateral where each member of the group applies pressure on other members to ensure repayment.

He receives monthly social assistance in the amount of 150 KM (about US$ 120). They have 3 children ranging from 14-27 years old. The oldest son is employed and he can earn about 1500 KM (about US$ 1200) monthly.  Rasma will use this loan in the amount of US$ 500 to buy feed for their livestock. Her wish is to improve living standards for her children by selling milk and milk products.

loans.use: To buy feed for livestock

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina is a fifty-two-year old married mother of three children. All of the children are grown, except for the youngest, who is in polytechnical school.

Paulina has been selling bananas and plantains in Accra’s busy Agblogbloshie market for over twenty years. She purchases her products through suppliers and then sells them to local hotels, restaurants, and streetside vendors in Accra. She will use the loan to expand her inventory of bananas and plantains and guard against price hikes. She hopes to use the proceeds of her increased sales to complete the rebuilding of her house.

Paulina is a member of the "Awurade Kae Me" (Remember Me, God) lending group. The lending group works with a type of social collateral where each member of the group applies pressure on other members to ensure repayment.

loans.use: To buy more plantains and bananas in bulk quantities

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Maimuna, who has business dealing in goats and chicken sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Maimuna, who has a business dealing in goats and chicken sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more utensils for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Mwandaima, who has a business dealing in fish sales.

Mwantumu is 38 years old and is married woman with 5 children, ages 5-25 years old. Mwantumu is a utensils product seller, she started in 1992. Everyday, she works from 8am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more utensils product for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Mwandaima, who has business dealing in Fish sales.

loans.name: Adelaide

texts.en:
Adelaide is twenty-three years old and an single. She has been selling jewelry and different varieties of beads in Cape Coast for the past five years. Beads are precious ornaments (jewels) to women in Ghana, because they signify purity, beauty, and fertility and also to control weight. It is also believed to announce the presence of a woman to a man. Therefore, there is a high demand for such products.

Adelaide wants to expand her operation, so she wants to use her loan to buy more and varieties of beads and other metallic jewels for her customers.

She is a member of the group called "Our Helper." Members agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more hair ribbons, jewelry, and beads.

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en:
Faustina N. is a trader who owns a provisions store. She is married and has 4 children. She is working very hard, and business is doing very well. She wants to increase sales and maximize profit, but her problem is a lack of adequate capital.

She is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more goods for sale

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a fifty-two-year old married mother of five children and eight grandchildren. She has been selling bananas and plantains in Accra’s busy Agblogbloshie market for over thirty years.

She purchases her products through suppliers and then sells them to local hotels, restaurants, and streetside vendors in Accra. She will use the loan to expand her inventory of bananas and plantains and guard against price hikes. She hopes to use the proceeds of her increased sales to build a house some day.

Rose is a member of the "Awurade Kae Me" (Remember Me, God) lending group. The lending group use a type of social collateral where each member of the group applies pressure on other members to ensure repayment.

loans.use: To buy more bananas and plantains

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
M. Francis is a dealer of electrical products. He is married and has 3 children. Business is doing very well, and he wishes to increase sales but lacks adequate funding.

He is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more goods for sale

loans.name: Matale Lending Group 1

texts.en:
Christine Aslimwe, the group representative, is a 30-year-old mother of three. She also cares for her late sister's three children. All six of the children in her care attend schools for which she and her husband have to find the school fees.

Christine has had a retail shop at Matale for three years. Her dream is to develop the shop into a wholesale store by expanding its size and slowly slowly having the resources to buy in bulk for cheaper prices. For now, she wants to use the loan to add a second fridge to the shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To pay for the group's various businesses and daily expenses.

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac S. is a dealer of home appliances. He is married and has 4 children. His wife is helping him meet the family’s needs. Business is doing very well, and he wishes to improve the business.

He is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more goods (appliances) for sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more goods (appliances) for sale

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort is a fifty-nine-year old widowed mother of five children and eight grandchildren. She sells maize and plantains in Accra’s busy Agblogbloshie market. She purchases her products through suppliers and then sells them to local hotels, restaurants, and streetside vendors in Accra.

She will use the loan to expand her inventory of maize and plantains and guard against price hikes. She hopes to use the proceeds of her increased sales to build a house some day.

Comfort is a member of the "Awurade Kae Me" (Remember Me, God) lending group. The lending group uses a type of social collateral where each member of the group applies pressure on other members to ensure repayment.

loans.use: To buy more maize and plantains

loans.name: Matale Lending Group 2

texts.en:
This group is from a small village, 30 minutes drive down a dust road, around 50 miles, from Kampala. Robina Negesse represents the group. Robina is a 35- year-old single mother of five. The father of her children does not help with any maintenance costs. Her children range in age from 7 to 15 years and all attend school. She also cares for her late sister's two children. The fees for her seven children to go to school are very expensive.

Robina has a bar in her village, where she works alone and from which she sells beer, soda and a locally made brew. She has had the bar for 10 years and has been borrowing funds from PEARL Micro Finance for four years. She wants a new loan to enable to her to continue paying the fees at her bar and to purchase stock in greater quantites, saving her money.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To pay for the group members' various businesses and daily expenses.

loans.name: Mwanshasha's Group

texts.en:
Mwanshasha is married with 4 children, ages 15 to 26. Mwanshasha owns a small food vending store, which she started in 2007. Every day she works from 6:30 AM to 8:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Bituni, who has a business dealing in fish sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items (Irish potatoes, rice, flour, etc) for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Ebo

texts.en:
Ebo M. is in the telecommunications business; he also sells phone credits. He is a single parent with 1 child. He wants to expand and improve his business but lacks capital.

He is asking for $525 as additional capital to enable him to improve the conditions of his business.

loans.use: As additional capital to enable him to improve the conditions of his business

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph Y. is a professional barber who owns a salon. He is married and has 2 children. Business is doing very well, and customers are increasing considerably. He wishes to improve his services to his clients to attract more customers.

He is asking for $525 as additional funds to expand his business.

loans.use: As additional funds to expand his business

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a forty-seven-year old married mother of four children. She sells maize and plantains in Accra’s busy Agblogbloshie market. She purchases her products through suppliers and then sells them to local hotels, restaurants, and streetside vendors in Accra.

She will use the loan to expand her inventory of maize and plantains and guard against price hikes. She hopes to use the proceeds of her increased sales to build a house some day.

Joyce is a member of the "Awurade Kae Me" (Remember Me, God) lending group. The lending group uses a type of social collateral where each member of the group applies pressure on other members to ensure repayment.

loans.use: To buy more bananas and plantains

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John Y. deals in electrical items. He is married and has 2 children. He is working very hard to improve the lives of his family. He wishes to increase his income by increasing sales. His problem is adequate funds to purchase more goods to meet the demand of his customers.

He is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more goods for sale

loans.name: Mwanahawa's Uwenacho Group

texts.en:
Mwanahawa is 31 years old and is married with 1 child, age 7. Mwanahawa owns a small food vending store, and she is a cloth seller, which she started in 2005. Every day she works from 7:00 AM to 8:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Elizabeth, who has a business dealing in fish sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Uwezo's Uwenacho Group

texts.en:
Uwezo is 28 years old and is divorced with 1 child, age 3. Uwezo is a cow seller; she started her business in 2006. Every day she works from 7:00 AM to 6:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to expand her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Mwanaisha, who has a business dealing in cloth sales.

loans.use: To expand her cow business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Mariam's Uwenacho Group

texts.en:
Mariam is 27 years old and is married with 2 children, ages 11 and 8. Mariam owns a small food vending store, and she is a cosmetics seller, which she started in 1995. Every day she works from 6:00 AM to 4:30 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $48 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items and cosmetics items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Bahati, who has a business dealing in food vending.

loans.use: To buy more food items and cosmetics items for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Saumu's Sasa Kazi Group

texts.en:
Saumu is 20 years old and is a single woman. Saumu is a shoes seller; she started her business in 2008. Every day she works from 8:00 AM to 4:30 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more shoes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Rukia, who has a business dealing in fish sales.

loans.use: To buy more shoes for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Adamu

texts.en:
Adamu T. A. is a dealer of electrical products. He is married and has 6 dependents. Demand for his goods has increased, but he lacks enough capital to purchase goods to meet the demand of his customers.

He is asking for $525 as additional capital to purchase more goods to meet the demand of his customers.

loans.use: As additional capital to purchase more goods to meet the demand of his customers

loans.name: Martina

texts.en:
Martina O. is a seamstress. She is married and has 3 children. She is working very hard to help her husband meet the financial needs of the family. She wants to improve her services to attract more customers.

She is asking for $525 as additional capital for the expansion of her business.

loans.use: As additional capital for the expansion of her business

loans.name: Akyea

texts.en:
Akyea J. is a wholesale dealer in electrical and general goods. He is married but has no child. Demand for his goods is increasing by the day. But his capital is not sufficient to meet the demand of his customers.

He is asking for $525 as additional capital to enable him to buy more goods for sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to enable him to buy more goods for sale

loans.name: Maria Patricia

texts.es:
. Maria Patricia is a physiotherapist and she works at a medical center from Monday through Friday. She has a young daughter who attends school and she is separated from her husband and the only person to generate an income for the family. She lives in the area of Miraflores in the town of La Paz. It is the second time she requests a loan and her credit history reports her as a number 1 client meaning that she has fulfilled her obligations repaying satisfactorily.
